revision.text:
'''Aesthetic judgement''', often also referred to as ‘taste’, is a concept in [[aesthetics]] which attempts to explain the nature of judgements of [[beauty]] and whether or not these judgements are legitimate.
The key idea for most traditional theories of taste was that objects possessed concrete properties that the perceiver ought to judge as beautiful or not. Failure to make the correct judgement was considered as something deficient within the beholder, whether that be a flaw within the person’s virtue or connected to a lack of knowledge that hinders their ability to perceive the beauty of the object.
Aesthetic judgement as a concept rose to prominence in the eighteenth century, however its roots can be traced back many years to ancient Greek and medieval philosophers.
== Ancient conceptions of aesthetic judgement == [[File:Sanzio 01 Plato Aristotle.jpg|thumb|The central image from Raphael's ''[[The School of Athens]]'' (1509-1511), depicting Plato (left) and Aristotle (right). Plato is depicted pointing upwards, in reference to his theory of forms, whilst Aristotle disagrees and points down towards reality, in reference to his belief in [[empiricism]].]] [[Ancient Greek philosophy|Ancient Greek philosophers]] did not possess an explicit concept of aesthetic judgement, however their ideas regarding aesthetics inspired later developments.
=== Plato === [[Plato|Plato’s]] [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] theory held that there is an incorporeal realm in which the perfect [[Theory of forms|Forms]] of reality exist. This includes the perfect Form of Beauty, which one can rise up to through a [[Dialectic|dialectical]] method. Thus, in Plato’s terms, knowledge is critical to developing a better understanding of beauty and thus, a better capacity for aesthetic judgement.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iep.utm.edu/a-taste/|title=Aesthetic Taste|last=Spicher|first=Michael|date=|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Aristotle === [[Aristotle]] purported a more [[Experiential knowledge|experiential]] approach to aesthetic judgement, in that beauty was a property of objects being related to their size and proportion. To develop a capacity for aesthetic judgement, one has to observe enough objects of the same kind to uncover the correct form of those things. Both Aristotle and Plato perceived beauty as a property existing outside of human experience, with aesthetic judgement being the capacity to recognise that beauty, developed by the search for beauty in things.<ref name=":0" />
== Medieval conceptions of aesthetic judgement == Although Medieval philosophers did not possess a particular notion of individual preference or taste, they were particularly preoccupied with a [[Cosmology|cosmological]] interpretation of beauty, with relation to specific [[Ontology|ontological]] properties. This is attributed to the fact that philosophers of the medieval age had an object notion of beauty, and also because it was a common belief that morality was linked with beauty.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Marinescu|first=Axia|date=2014-01-01|title=Beauty and Judgement in German Aesthetics|url=https://content.sciendo.com/view/journals/hssr/3/1/article-p124.xml|journal=Human & Social Studies. Research and Practice|language=en|volume=3|issue=1|doi=10.2478/hssr-2013-0024|issn=2285-5920}}</ref>
=== Augustine of Hippo === Expanding upon Plato’s Theory of the Forms, [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] believed that perfect beauty existed within God. Augustine proposed equality and unity as the two properties that made physical objects beautiful. Aesthetic judgement is thus the ability of an individual to recognise the unity and equality of an object, thus involving an exercise of reason and knowledge, similar to the theories of previous thinkers.<ref name=":0" /> Since the ultimate state of beauty exists in God’s mind, an observer can only recognise this through [[divine illumination]]. Thus, one’s capacity for aesthetic judgement is improved the closer one is to God.
=== Thomas Aquinas === [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]] also presented properties that make an object beautiful: proportion, wholeness and radiance. Thus, similar to his philosophical predecessors, he constituted the judgement of beauty to be dependent on knowledge and occurring through the function of cognition. Possessing a capacity for aesthetic judgement is therefore determined by one’s ability to recognise these properties in observed objects. Aquinas does however diverge from previous philosophers on certain notions. His definition of that beauty as "that which, when seen, pleases" can be interpreted as an implication of the subjectivity of beauty and thus judgements about it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wood|first=Robert E.|date=2015-06-23|title=Review of Aquinas on Beauty|url=https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/aquinas-on-beauty/|issn=1538-1617}}</ref> Furthermore, he rejects Plato’s Theory of Forms, stating that beauty is a real quality present within objects. Ultimately however he converges upon Augustine’s view that God is the source of all beauty.<ref name=":0" />
== 18th century theories of aesthetic judgement == Explicit theories of aesthetic judgement emerged and predominated in the 18<sup>th</sup> century, being referred to as “the century of taste”.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/435824318|title=The century of taste : the philosophical odyssey of taste in the eighteenth century|last=1926-|first=Dickie, George,|date=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195357134|location=New York|oclc=435824318}}</ref> Philosophers developed a more introspective stance to attempt to understand their personal dispositions to beauty.
=== Anthony Cooper, the Third Earl of Shaftesbury === [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury|Anthony Cooper]] (1671-1713), the Third Earl of Shaftesbury, purported his philosophical ideas through his [[Socratic dialogue]] “The Moralists, a Philosophical Rhapsody”, which stands in almost direct contrast to the theories and assumptions posited by Addison.<ref name=":1">{{Citation|last=Shelley|first=James|title=18th Century British Aesthetics|date=2018|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2018/entries/aesthetics-18th-british/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2018|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Shaftesbury claimed that taste was a quality innate within human beings. One’s capacity to observe and make correct judgements of beauty was dependent on one’s moral righteousness. The key property Shaftesbury ascribed to beautiful objects is harmony, the prime source of which is nature, which in turn is formed by God who is constituted as the ultimate source of beauty.
=== Joseph Addison === [[Joseph Addison]] (1672-1719) posited theories that were in almost direct contrast to those of Shaftesbury. Central to Addison’s theory of aesthetic judgement is the concept that pleasures of taste are essentially “pleasures of the imagination”.<ref name=":1" /> Addison’s fundamental divergence from Shaftesbury is that he views taste to be a judgement of visual representation as exercised by the imagination, rather than as an exercise of the intellect and of moral righteousness. Addison constituted two types of pleasures of the imagination: primary pleasures, as in those derived from visual images directly observed by an individual of an object in front of them and secondary pleasures, which arise from images of objects that are absent from sight and therefore exist only in the mind. Addison’s materialist basis predisposes his theory to subjectivism and relativism, leading Addison to declare that there “is not perhaps any real beauty”.<ref name=":1" />
=== Alexander Gerard === [[Alexander Gerard]] (1728-1795) considered taste in a similar fashion to the six external [[Sense|senses]], in that experiences of aesthetic judgement are also simple and instantaneous. He also developed his views from the philosophical framework of [[associationism]]. Aesthetic judgements are exercises of the faculty of imagination, in which a newly observed object is associated to previous ideas in the mind of the observer.<ref name=":0" /> Gerard determines that taste is improved when a person exercises their capacities for judgment and taste to recognise the four core elements of sensibility, refinement, correctness and proportion within objects.
== David Hume's theory of taste == David Hume’s theories on aesthetic judgement were purported in his 1757 essay ''[[Four Dissertations|Of the Standard of Taste]]''. Hume ascribed some normative quality to aesthetic judgements whilst providing critiques of the more relativist positions on the matter. Whilst acknowledging that judgements cannot reasonably be determined to be objectively true or false, he championed the notion of “common sense”, which held that some evaluations are better than others.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://web.mnstate.edu/gracyk/courses/phil%20of%20art/hume_and_kant.htm|title=Aesthetic theories of David Hume and Immanuel Kant|website=web.mnstate.edu|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Hume also reinforced the conception of aesthetic judgements as an exercise of the faculty of the imagination, determining beauty to not be a property of objects but existing only in the mind, and the ones that are deemed more beautiful are the ones that affect the higher sentiments, or high cognitive or intellectual capacities of the observer. Hume also sought to establish a universal standard of aesthetic judgement, seeking a basis upon which we can “confirm” one sentiment and “condemn” another.<ref name=":2" /> In doing this he refers to [[Classic book|classic texts]] which seemingly have received universal acclaim beyond through different times and cultures. Hume asserts that such universal acclamation identifies a work of real genius, and such works should be examined to provide us with guidelines for the composition of good art. Hume provides characteristics of what he refers to as a true judge in matters of aesthetics: [[File:Painting of David Hume.jpg|thumb|''Portrait of David Hume'' ''(1711-1776)'']] {{Quote|text="Strong sense, united to delicate sentiment, improved by practice, perfected by comparison, and cleared of all prejudice”|sign=David Hume|source="Four Dissertations", Of the Standard of Taste}}The consensus of these critics constitutes what Hume called a “joint verdict”<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/aesthetic-judgment|title=Aesthetic Judgment {{!}} Encyclopedia.com|website=www.encyclopedia.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>, which composes the "true standard"<ref name=":2" /> for aesthetic judgements. This standard is constituted as universally correct, and failure to recognise pleasure in the object is considered a defect within the observer.
Hume does concede however that certain subjectivities affecting aesthetic judgements cannot be eliminated. He indicates two circumstances that will create irrevocable prejudices. First he refers to natural, generational and cultural dispositions which are fundamental and relative to individuals. The second is determined by the critics’ degree of moral righteousness. Ascribing a normative characteristic to morality, Hume declares that aesthetic merit is influenced by “the natural boundaries of vice and virtue”<ref name=":2" />, and if the artist does not conform to these moral regulations then they and their art will inevitably divert from Hume’s true standard.
== Immanuel Kant's "judgement of taste" == Central to the concept of aesthetic judgement is Kant’s notion of the “judgement of taste”, introduced in his seminal 1790 book the ''[[Critique of Judgment|Critique of Judgement]].'' In the text, Kant determined two essential conditions for a judgement to be classified as a judgement of taste – subjectivity and universality.
Subjectivity refers to the fact that a judgement of taste is based on a feeling of pleasure or displeasure. The second necessary condition of a judgement of taste is that it claims “universal validity”, which Kant describes as follows:
{{Quote|text=“… when [a man] puts a thing on a pedestal and calls it beautiful, he demands the same delight from others. He judges not merely from himself, but for all men, and then speaks of beauty as if it were a property of things”|sign=Immanuel Kant|source=Critique of Judgement}} Kant emphasises the fact that requiring the agreement of others is an inextricable characteristic of aesthetic judgements. We think that others “ought” to share our judgement, and we blame them if they don’t, as if there was a deficiency within them to recognise beauty and make judgements upon it.<ref>{{Citation|last=Zangwill|first=Nick|title=Aesthetic Judgment|date=2014|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2014/entries/aesthetic-judgment/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2014|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Aesthetic judgements, unique from other types of judgements that Kant lists, therefore make a claim to universal validity. Kant also states that pleasure in beauty is disinterested in that it is desire-free. Whilst agreeing that pleasure in beauty can generate desire, he states that it is an essential characteristic of aesthetic judgements that they are found to be pleasurable because they are judged to be beautiful, rather than being judged as beautiful because they are found to be pleasurable.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iep.utm.edu/kantaest/#SH2a|title=Immanuel Kant: Aesthetics|last=Burnham|first=Douglas|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref>
Kant provides a “deep” account of the nature of pleasure in beauty, which states that it accomplished through the simultaneous exercise of the cognitive faculties of imagination and understanding.<ref name=":4" /> This is the premise upon which Kant asserts his normative claim on aesthetic judgements. Because these judgements are a function of cognitive faculties, which Kant assumed can be shared by humans, it must be possible for them to be shared. Kant also purported that pleasure in beauty can be attributed to our recognition that the qualities of an object conform to basic functions of human cognition. We maintain a presupposition that all objects seemed to be formed in a way that enables them to be analysed by human observers. Beauty is the quality of an object assuming a “form of purposiveness”, despite the absence of an identification of a specific purpose.<ref name=":2" /> When we respond to an object’s appearance without any comprehension of utility, we respond in an aesthetic manner. The feeling of pleasure is a signal that the object is able to be comprehended through exercising the human faculty of understanding. An aesthetic judgement is therefore a judgement about human cognition rather than a material object.
== Nineteenth and twentieth century theories of aesthetic judgement == Philosophical concerns with aesthetic judgement declined rapidly after the 19<sup>th</sup> century, with the majority of discourse shifting to the concept of an aesthetic attitude.<ref name=":0" /> Despite this, there have been philosophers who have persisted with the concept of aesthetic taste, which has resulted in some notable contributions in contemporary times.
=== Frank Sibley === [[Frank Sibley (philosopher)|Frank Sibley]] (1929-1996) defined aesthetic judgements to be evaluations that apply aesthetic concepts to objects through aesthetic terminology. Taste is thus an individual’s capacity to recognise these properties and employ aesthetic concepts and terms appropriately to describe them.<ref name=":3" /> Sibley also asserts that aesthetic judgements are objective and that beauty is an objective property present within objects, departing from the 18<sup>th</sup> century philosophical norm of subjectivist interpretation.
== References ==
[[Category:Aesthetics]]

{{short description|a theory of jurisprudence}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2017}} '''Analytical jurisprudence''' is a theory of [[jurisprudence]] that draws on the resources of modern [[analytical philosophy]] to try to understand the nature of law. Since the boundaries of analytical philosophy are somewhat vague, it is difficult to say how far it extends. [[H. L. A. Hart]] was probably the most influential writer in the modern school of analytical jurisprudence,<ref>Bodenheimer, Edgar, [http://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=7496&context=penn_law_review Modern Analytical Jurisprudence and the Limits of Its Usefulness], [[University of Pennsylvania Law Review]]</ref> though its history goes back at least to [[Jeremy Bentham]].
Analytical jurisprudence is not to be mistaken for [[legal formalism]] (the idea that legal reasoning is or can be modelled as a mechanical, algorithmic process). Indeed, it was the analytical jurists who first pointed out that legal formalism is fundamentally mistaken as a theory of law.
Analytic, or 'clarificatory' jurisprudence uses a neutral point of view and descriptive language when referring to the aspects of legal systems. This was a philosophical development that rejected [[natural law]]'s fusing of what law is and what it ought to be. [[David Hume]] famously argued in ''[[A Treatise of Human Nature]]'' that people invariably slip between describing that the world is a certain way to saying therefore we ought to conclude on a particular course of action. But as a matter of pure logic, one cannot conclude that we ought to do something merely because something is the case. So analysing and clarifying the way the world is, must be treated as a strictly separate question to normative and evaluative [[is–ought problem|ought questions]].
The most important questions of analytic jurisprudence are: "[[Definition of law|What are laws]]?"; "What is the law?"; "What is the relationship between law and [[power (social and political)|power]]?"; and, "What is the relationship between law and [[morality]]?" [[Legal positivism]] is the dominant theory, although there are a growing number of critics, who offer their own interpretations.
[[Springer books]] commissioned essays on analytical jurisprudence for ''A Treatise on Legal Philosophy and General Jurisprudence''. {{ISBN|9781402033872}} * Volume 1: Legal ontology and epistemology by Pattero * Volume 2: Legal foundations by Rottleuthner * Volume 3: Sources and institutions of law by Shiner<ref>[[Jan Woleński]] (2007) "Review: Legal Philosophy and General Jurisprudence volumes 1 to 3", ''Ratio Juris'' 20(1): 136–43, {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9337.2007.00351.x}}</ref> * Volume 4: Legal doctrine by Peczenik * Volume 5: Legal reasoning by Sartor<ref>J. Woleński (2007) "Review: LP & GJ v 4,5", ''Ratio Juris'' 20(3): 424–31 {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9337.2007.00368.x}}</ref> * Volume 6: History to early modern scholasticism edited by Miller and Biondi * Volume 7: Rome, Middle Ages, & Politics edited by Padovani & Stein * Volume 8: Various including Blackstone & Bentham by Michael Lobban<ref>J. Woleński (2008) "Review: LP & GJ v 6,7,8", ''Ratio Juris'' 21(3): 412–19 {{doi|10.1111/j.1467-9337.2008.00398.x}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Rule of law]] *[[Legality]] *[[Rule According to Higher Law]]

[[File:Map of Bengal.svg|thumb|260px|Map of the Bengal.]] {{Bengalis}} '''Baṅgamātā''' ({{lang-bn|বঙ্গমাতা}}), '''Mother Bengal''' or simply '''বাংলা'''/ '''Bangla''', a [[national personification|personification]] of [[Bengal]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Bharat Mata, more benign|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/bharat-mata-more-benign-2853150/|work=The Indian Express|date=15 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Singh|first1=Amritjit|last2=Iyer|first2=Nalini|last3=Gairola|first3=Rahul K.|title=Revisiting India's Partition: New Essays on Memory, Culture, and Politics|date=2016|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=9781498531054|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=tmA0DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA98&lpg=PA98&dq=bangamata+poem+rabindranath+tagore&source=bl&ots=-e6nZu-Y_E&sig=gnj-GF2Ldxr7RkpEE6DjRwRGXto&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ25Wmwc7RAhVsBcAKHUuKCOo4FBDoAQgfMAE#v=onepage&q=bangamata%20poem%20rabindranath%20tagore&f=false|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Hindu : Patriotic fervour|url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mag/2003/08/17/stories/2003081700160200.htm|website=www.thehindu.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bose|first1=Sugata|last2=Jalal|first2=Ayesha|title=Modern South Asia: History, Culture, Political Economy|date=1998|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=9780415169523|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=bodaohHyDRcC&pg=PA121&lpg=PA121&dq=bangamata+poem+rabindranath+tagore&source=bl&ots=RwbN_8IILV&sig=4lo6w4B3k_IY5BJi1XGJu-A6Jgg&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ25Wmwc7RAhVsBcAKHUuKCOo4FBDoAQgZMAA#v=onepage&q=bangamata%20poem%20rabindranath%20tagore&f=false|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Gupta|first1=Swarupa|title=Notions of Nationhood in Bengal: Perspectives on Samaj, c. 1867-1905|date=2009|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789047429586|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=b9SwCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA323&lpg=PA323&dq=bangamata+poem+rabindranath+tagore&source=bl&ots=eLOHckYKps&sig=Az72zLs3qAARzdwUJNvGEE6Lkbs&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZ25Wmwc7RAhVsBcAKHUuKCOo4FBDoAQgjMAI#v=onepage&q=bangamata%20poem%20rabindranath%20tagore&f=false|language=en}}</ref> was created during [[Bengali renaissance]] and later adopted by the [[Bengali nationalism|Bengali nationalists]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=0HrBJJBFutsC&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=bangamata+rabindranath+tagore&source=bl&ots=6jGQ4z_s--&sig=i6CD3KxObpZ7zO1PWqt_vYJVfiw&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjdjKiQy6HQAhUDPRoKHWWND0kQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=bangamata+rabindranath+tagore&f=false|title=Social Thought of Rabindranath Tagore: A Historical Analysis|first=Tapati|last=Dasgupta|date=16 August 1993|publisher=Abhinav Publications|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=Ey1v6JEmvakC&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=bangamata+rabindranath+tagore&source=bl&ots=gDHX-Lx94I&sig=5QhYqls7KFF5bHqKYYll-uGUxX0&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjdjKiQy6HQAhUDPRoKHWWND0kQ6AEIVTAN#v=onepage&q=bangamata+rabindranath+tagore&f=false|title=Science, Spirituality and the Modernization of India|first=Makarand|last=Paranjape|date=14 May 2014|publisher=Anthem Press|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://appweb.cortland.edu/ojs/index.php/Wagadu/article/viewArticle/250/464|title=Symbols of Water and Woman on Selected Examples of Modern Bengali Literature in the Context of Mythological Tradition|publisher=|access-date=12 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212184455/http://appweb.cortland.edu/ojs/index.php/Wagadu/article/viewArticle/250/464|archive-date=12 December 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="deccanchronicle.com">{{cite web| url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/opinion/op-ed/220316/thinking-allowed-feeling-seditious-or-patriotic.html| title=Thinking Allowed: Feeling seditious or patriotic?| publisher= [[Deccan Chronicle]]| accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref> In Bangladeshi poetry, literature and patriotic song, she has become a symbol of [[Bangladesh]], considered as a personification of the Republic. The Mother Bengal represents not only biological motherness but its attributed characteristics as well – protection, never ending love, consolation, care, the beginning and the end of life.
[[Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay]], an orthodox Brahmin writer, poet and journalist, composed an Ode to Mother Bengal called [[Vande Mataram]] around 1876 as an alternative to the British royal anthem.<ref>[[Sri Aurobindo]] commented on his English translation of the poem, "It is difficult to translate the National Anthem of Bengal into verse in another language owing to its unique union of sweetness, simple directness and high poetic force." Quoted in Bhabatosh Chatterjee (ed.), ''Bankim Chandra Chatterjee: Essays in Perspective'', Sahitya Akademi, Delhi, 1994, p. 601.</ref>
In [[Amar Sonar Bangla]], the national anthem of Bangladesh, [[Rabindranath Tagore]] used the word "Maa" (Mother) numerous times to refer to the motherland, ''i.e.'' Bengal. Despite her popularity in patriotic songs and poems, her physical representations and images are rare.
==History== ===Partition of Bengal (1905)=== During the period of বঙ্গভঙ্গ Bônggôbhônggô<ref>John R. McLane, "The Decision to Partition Bengal in 1905," ''Indian Economic and Social History Review,'' July 1965, 2#3, pp 221–237</ref><ref name="britannica.com">{{cite web|publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]|title=Partition of Bengal|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/60754/partition-of-Bengal|accessdate=2017-08-18}}</ref> ([[Partition of Bengal (1905)]]) - when the ruling British empire had the province of [[Bengal]] (of undivided India) split into two parts, many Bengali intellectuals joined cultural and political movement against the partition. The partition took place in October 1905 and separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas. The Hindus of West Bengal who dominated Bengal's business and rural life complained that the division would make them a minority in a province that would incorporate the [[Bihar and Orissa Province]].<ref name="britannica.com"/> It was during this time the Mother Bengal was an immensely popular theme in Bengali patriotic songs and poems and was mentioned in several of them, such as the song ″[[Dhana Dhanya Pushpa Bhara]]″ and ″[[Banga Amar Janani Amar]]″ (Our Bengal Our Mother) by [[Dwijendralal Ray]]. These songs were meant to rekindle the unified spirit of Bengal, to raise public consciousness against the communal political divide.
===Bangladesh Liberation War=== Many of Bengali patriotic songs were regularly played on the [[Swadhin Bangla Betar Kendra]], the clandestine radio station broadcast to revolutionaries and occupied population during the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]].<ref name=start>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/1971-and-the-songs-we-sang/|title=1971 and the songs we sang|accessdate=2013-12-13|date=2012-12-01|author=Syed Badrul Ahsan|publisher=The Daily Star}}</ref> some of these patriotic songs, such as “Jonmo Amar Dhonno Holo Maa-go” and “Bangla Moder Bangla Maa Amra Tomar Koti Shontan” have significant representations of “Mother Bengal”. She was an icon of freedom and [[democracy]] against all forms of dictatorship. These patriotic songs are still immensely popular in [[Bangladesh]] and [[West Bengal]] .
==In art and literature== * [[Vande Mataram]], by [[Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay]] * [[Banga Amar Janani Amar]], by [[Dwijendralal Ray]] * [[Bangamata (poem)]], by [[Rabindranath Tagore]] * [[Amar Sonar Bangla]], by [[Rabindranath Tagore]] in 1905 * [[Bangladesh (poem)|Bangladesh]], by [[Kazi Nazrul Islam]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abrittiokobita.wordpress.com/2014/06/09/%e0%a6%ac%e0%a6%be%e0%a6%82%e0%a6%b2%e0%a6%be%e0%a6%a6%e0%a7%87%e0%a6%b6/|title=বাংলাদেশ|date=9 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Aaji Bangladesher Hridoy]], by [[Rabindranath Tagore]] In his patriotic song, known as ''Aaji Bangladesher Hridoy'' (1905), the poet Rabindranath Tagore wrote the following depiction of Bangladesh, or the then undivided Bengal (not to be confused with the modern-day country of 'Bangladesh', with 'Bangla' meaning Bengal and 'Desh' meaning Land):<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.geetabitan.com/lyrics/A/aaji-bangladesher-hridoy.html |title=Lyric aaji bangladesher hridoy |website=geetabitan.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017144200/http://www.geetabitan.com/lyrics/A/aaji-bangladesher-hridoy.html |archive-date=2012-10-17}}</ref> :When did you come out of the heart of Bangladesh, :O, Mother dear, with such inexplicable splendor! :It’s impossible to take away eyes from you! :The doors of your golden temple have unlocked. :Your right hand holds the blazing sword, the left one takes away fear, :Smile of affection on the eyes, the third eye glaring. :O Mother dear, how uniquely you reveal yourself! :The cloud of your untied hair conceals thunders :Ends of your sunlight coloured robes flutter in the horizon! :It’s impossible to take away eyes from you! :The doors of your golden temple have unlocked. :When impassionately did not look up seemed :Poor mother stayed back home , desolate, destitute. :Your torn clothes vanish now, meager smile disappear. :Beams of light scatter from your feet into entire sky :O Mother, your appearance astounds me. :You flood the world with the flow of happiness on the distressed nights :O the mindblower, your word of fearlessness drum the heart :It’s impossible to take away eyes from you! :The doors of your golden temple have unlocked.
This is most probably only picturesque details of Mother Bengal.

[[File:Brooklyn Museum - Blind Men Appraising an Elephant - Ohara Donshu.jpg|thumb|''Blind Men Appraising an Elephant'' by Ohara Donshu, Edo Period (early 19th century), Brooklyn Museum]] [[File:Blind men and elephant.jpg|thumb|Blind men and elephant]] The [[parable]] of the '''blind men and an elephant''' originated in the ancient [[Indian subcontinent]], from where it has been widely diffused. However the meaning of the popular [[proverb]] differs in other countries. It is a story of a group of blind men, who have never come across an [[elephant]] before and who learn and conceptualize what the elephant is like by touching it. Each blind man feels a different part of the elephant's body, but only one part, such as the side or the tusk. They then describe the elephant based on their limited experience and their descriptions of the elephant are different from each other. In some versions, they come to suspect that the other person is dishonest and they come to blows. The moral of the parable is that humans have a tendency to claim absolute truth based on their limited, subjective experience as they ignore other people's limited, subjective experiences which may be equally true.{{cite book|author=E. Bruce Goldstein|title=Encyclopedia of Perception|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6M3NSNm6MlkC&pg=PA492|year=2010|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-4081-8|page=492}}, '''Quote:''' The ancient Hindu parable of the six blind men and the elephant...." The first version of the story itself is traceable to the Buddhist text ''Udana 6.4'', dated to about mid 1st millennium BCE. According to John Ireland, the parable is likely older than the Buddhist text.{{cite book|author=John D. Ireland|title=Udana and the Itivuttaka: Two Classics from the Pali Canon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kIllG8k-OmIC |year=2007|publisher=Buddhist Publication Society|isbn=978-955-24-0164-0|pages=9, 81–84}} An alternate version of the parable describes normal men, experiencing a large statue on a dark night, or feeling a large object while being blindfolded. They then describe what it is they have experienced. In its various versions, it is a parable that has crossed between many religious traditions and is part of [[Buddhist]], [[Hindu]] and [[Jainism|Jain]] texts of 1st millennium CE or before.{{cite book|author=Paul J. Griffiths|title=An Apology for Apologetics: A Study in the Logic of Interreligious Dialogue|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7jRKAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA46|year=2007|publisher=Wipf and Stock|isbn=978-1-55635-731-2|pages=46–47}} The story also appears in 2nd millennium [[Sufi]] and [[Baha'i Faith|Bahá’í]] lore. The tale later became well known in Europe, with 19th century American poet [[John Godfrey Saxe]] creating [[s:The Blind Men and the Elephant|his own version]] as a poem, with a final verse that explains that the elephant is a metaphor for God, and the various blind men represent religions that disagree on something no one has fully experienced.{{cite book|author=Martin Gardner|title=Famous Poems from Bygone Days|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lTRorcYPLH0C&pg=PA124|accessdate=2012-08-25|date=1 September 1995|publisher=Courier Dover Publications|isbn=978-0-486-28623-5|page=124}} The story has been published in many books for adults and children, and interpreted in a variety of ways. ==The parable== {{anchor|The story}} The earliest versions of the parable of blind men and elephant is found in Buddhist, Hindu and Jain texts, as they discuss the limits of perception and the importance of complete context. The parable has several Indian variations, but broadly goes as follows:{{cite book|author=E. Bruce Goldstein|title=Encyclopedia of Perception|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6M3NSNm6MlkC&pg=PA492|year=2010|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4129-4081-8|page=492}}{{cite book|author1=C.R. Snyder|author2=Carol E. Ford|title=Coping with Negative Life Events: Clinical and Social Psychological Perspectives|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Bo7gBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA12|year= 2013|publisher=Springer Science |isbn=978-1-4757-9865-4|page=12}} {{Quote|A group of blind men heard that a strange animal, called an elephant, had been brought to the town, but none of them were aware of its shape and form. Out of curiosity, they said: "We must inspect and know it by touch, of which we are capable". So, they sought it out, and when they found it they groped about it. In the case of the first person, whose hand landed on the trunk, said "This being is like a thick snake". For another one whose hand reached its ear, it seemed like a kind of fan. As for another person, whose hand was upon its leg, said, the elephant is a pillar like a tree-trunk. The blind man who placed his hand upon its side said, "elephant is a wall". Another who felt its tail, described it as a rope. The last felt its tusk, stating the elephant is that which is hard, smooth and like a spear.}} [[File:Illustrated proverb- Blind men and an elephant.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The blind men and the elephant
(wall relief in Northeast Thailand)]] In some versions, the blind men then discover their disagreements, suspect the others to be not telling the truth and come to blows. The stories also differ primarily in how the elephant's body parts are described, how violent the conflict becomes and how (or if) the conflict among the men and their perspectives is resolved. In some versions, they stop talking, start listening and collaborate to "see" the full elephant. In another, a sighted man enters the parable and describes the entire elephant from various perspectives, the blind men then learn that they were all partially correct and partially wrong. While one's subjective experience is true, it may not be the totality of truth. The parable has been used to illustrate a range of truths and [[fallacies]]; broadly, the parable implies that one's subjective experience can be true, but that such experience is inherently limited by its failure to account for other truths or a totality of truth. At various times the parable has provided insight into the relativism, opaqueness or inexpressible nature of truth, the behavior of experts in fields of contradicting theories, the need for deeper understanding, and respect for different perspectives on the same object of observation. ==Hinduism== The ''Rigveda'', dated to have been composed between 1500 and 1200 BCE, states "Reality is one, though wise men speak of it variously." According to Paul J. Griffiths, this premise is the foundation of universalist perspective behind the parable of the blind men and an elephant. The hymn asserts that the same reality is subject to interpretations and described in various ways by the wise. In the oldest version, four blind men walk into a forest where they meet an elephant. In this version, they do not fight with each other, but conclude that they each must have perceived a different beast although they experienced the same elephant. The expanded version of the parable occurs in various ancient and Hindu texts. Many scholars refer to it as a Hindu parable.[a] {{cite book|author=Chad Meister|title=Philosophy of Religion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1egYDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 |year=2016|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-31475-8|pages=11–12}};
[b] {{cite book|author1=Jeremy P. Shapiro|author2=Robert D. Friedberg|author3=Karen K. Bardenstein|title=Child and Adolescent Therapy: Science and Art|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_89sAAAAMAAJ |year=2006 |publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-0-471-38637-7|pages=269, 314}};
[c] {{cite book|author1=Peter B. Clarke|author2=Peter Beyer|title=The World's Religions: Continuities and Transformations |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rBgn3xB75ZcC |year=2009|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-135-21100-4|pages=470–471}} The parable or references appear in ''[[bhasya]]'' (commentaries, secondary literature) in the Hindu traditions. For example, [[Adi Shankara]] mentions it in his ''bhasya'' on verse 5.18.1 of the ''[[Chandogya Upanishad]]'' as follows: {{Quote| ''etaddhasti darshana iva jatyandhah'' Translation: That is like people blind by birth in/when viewing an elephant. |Adi Shankara, Translator: Hans Henrich Hock{{cite book|author=Hans H Hock|editor=Edwin Francis Bryant and Laurie L. Patton|title=The Indo-Aryan Controversy: Evidence and Inference in Indian History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fHYnGde4BS4C&pg=PA282 |year= 2005|publisher =Routledge|isbn=978-0-7007-1463-6|page=282}}}} ==Jainism== [[File:Medieval Jain temple Anekantavada doctrine artwork.jpg|thumb|left|Seven blind men and an elephant parable at a Jain temple]] The medieval era Jain texts explain the concepts of ''[[anekāntavāda]]'' (or "many-sidedness") and ''[[Anekantavada#Sy.C4.81dv.C4.81da|syādvāda]]'' ("conditioned viewpoints") with the [[parable]] of the blind men and an elephant (''Andhgajanyāyah''), which addresses the manifold nature of truth. For example, this parable are found in ''Tattvarthaslokavatika'' of [[Vidyananda (8th-century Jain monk)|Vidyanandi]] (9th century) and ''Syādvādamanjari'' of Ācārya Mallisena (13th century). Mallisena uses the parable to argue that immature people deny various aspects of truth; deluded by the aspects they ''do'' understand, they deny the aspects they ''don't'' understand. "Due to extreme delusion produced on account of a partial viewpoint, the immature deny one aspect and try to establish another. This is the maxim of the blind (men) and the elephant."Mallisena, ''Syādvādamanjari'', 14:103–104. Dhruva, A.B. (1933) pp. 9–10. Mallisena also cites the parable when noting the importance of considering all viewpoints in obtaining a full picture of reality. "It is impossible to properly understand an entity consisting of infinite properties without the method of modal description consisting of all viewpoints, since it will otherwise lead to a situation of seizing mere sprouts (i.e., a superficial, inadequate cognition), on the maxim of the blind (men) and the elephant."Mallisena, ''Syādvādamanjari'', 19:75–77. Dhruva, A.B. (1933) pp. 23–25. ==Buddhism== [[File:Blind monks examining an elephant.jpg|right|thumb|380px|''Blind monks examining an elephant'', an [[ukiyo-e]] print by [[Hanabusa Itchō]] (1652–1724).]] [[Gautama Buddha|The Buddha]] twice uses the simile of blind men led astray. The earliest known version occurs in the text ''[[Udana]] 6.4''.{{cite journal | last=Gomez | first=Luis O. | title=Proto-Madhyamika in the Pali Canon | journal=Philosophy East and West | publisher=Univ of Hawaii Press | volume=26 | issue=2 | year=1976 | doi=10.2307/1398186 | page=164 note 73; 137–165}} In the ''Canki Sutta'' he describes a row of blind men holding on to each other as an example of those who follow an old text that has passed down from generation to generation.[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.095x.than.html Accesstoinsight.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060628152156/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.095x.than.html |date=2006-06-28 }} In the [[Udana]] (68–69)[http://www.katinkahesselink.net/tibet/blind-men-elephant.html Katinkahesselink.net] he uses the elephant parable to describe sectarian quarrels. A king has the blind men of the capital brought to the palace, where an elephant is brought in and they are asked to describe it.
When the blind men had each felt a part of the elephant, the king went to each of them and said to each: 'Well, blind man, have you seen the elephant? Tell me, what sort of thing is an elephant?'
The men assert the elephant is either like a pot (the blind man who felt the elephant's head), a [[winnowing|winnowing basket]] (ear), a [[plowshare]] (tusk), a [[plow]] (trunk), a [[granary]] (body), a [[Column|pillar]] (foot), a [[Mortar (masonry)|mortar]] (back), a [[pestle]] (tail) or a brush (tip of the tail). The men cannot agree with one another and come to blows over the question of what it is like and their dispute delights the king. The Buddha ends the story by comparing the blind men to preachers and scholars who are blind and ignorant and hold to their own views: "Just so are these preachers and scholars holding various views blind and unseeing.... In their ignorance they are by nature quarrelsome, wrangling, and disputatious, each maintaining reality is thus and thus." The Buddha then speaks the following verse: {{quote|O how they cling and wrangle, some who claim For preacher and monk the honored name! For, quarreling, each to his view they cling. Such folk see only one side of a thing.{{cite web |url=http://www.cs.princeton.edu/~rywang/berkeley/258/parable.html |title=The Blind Men and the Elephant |first =Randy |last=Wang |accessdate=2006-08-29}}}} ==Sufism== [[File:Blind men and elephant4.jpg|thumb|Blind men and the elephant.]] The [[Persian people|Persian]] [[Sufi]] [[poet]] [[Sanai]] of [[Ghazni]] (currently, [[Afghanistan]]) presented this [[teaching story]] in his ''The Walled Garden of Truth''.Included in [[Idries Shah]], ''[[Tales of the Dervishes]]'' {{ISBN|0-900860-47-2}} [[Octagon Press]] 1993. [[Rumi]], the 13th Century Persian poet and teacher of Sufism, included it in his [[Masnavi]]. In his retelling, "The Elephant in the Dark", some Hindus bring an elephant to be exhibited in a dark room. A number of men touch and feel the elephant in the dark and, depending upon where they touch it, they believe the elephant to be like a water spout (trunk), a fan (ear), a pillar (leg) and a throne (back). Rumi uses this story as an example of the limits of individual perception:
The sensual eye is just like the palm of the hand. The palm has not the means of covering the whole of the beast.{{cite web |title=71 – The Elephant in the dark, on the reconciliation of contrarieties |url=http://www.khamush.com/tales_from_masnavi.htm#The%20Elephant |work=Rumi – Tales from Masnavi |date=2004-05-09 |first=A.J. |last= Arberry |accessdate=2006-08-29}}
Rumi does not present a resolution to the conflict in his version, but states:
The eye of the Sea is one thing and the foam another. Let the foam go, and gaze with the eye of the Sea. Day and night foam-flecks are flung from the sea: oh amazing! You behold the foam but not the Sea. We are like boats dashing together; our eyes are darkened, yet we are in clear water.
Rumi ends his poem by stating "If each had a candle and they went in together the differences would disappear." For an adaptation of Rumi's poem, see this song version by David Wilcox [http://davidwilcox.com/index.php?page=songs&display=1998&category=Out_Beyond_Ideas here] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009233459/http://davidwilcox.com/index.php?page=songs&display=1998&category=Out_Beyond_Ideas |date=October 9, 2010 }}. ==John Godfrey Saxe== One of the most famous versions of the 19th century was the poem "[[s:The Blind Men and the Elephant|The Blind Men and the Elephant]]" by [[John Godfrey Saxe]] (1816–1887). [[File:Blind men and elephant3.jpg|right|thumb|350px| {{quote|And so these men of Indostan
    Disputed loud and long,
Each in his own opinion
    Exceeding stiff and strong,
Though each was partly in the right
    And all were in the wrong!
}}]] The poem begins: {{quote|It was six men of Indostan To learning much inclined, Who went to see the Elephant (Though all of them were blind), That each by observation Might satisfy his mind{{cite wikisource|plaintitle=The poems of John Godfrey Saxe|chapter=The Blind Men and the Elephant|last=Saxe|first=John Godfrey|authorlink=John Godfrey Saxe|wspage=260|scan=Page:The poems of John Godfrey Saxe.djvu/279}}}} Each in his own opinion concludes that the elephant is like a wall, snake, spear, tree, fan or rope, depending upon where they had touched. Their heated debate comes short of physical violence, but the conflict is never resolved. {{quote| '''Moral:''' So oft in theologic wars, The disputants, I ween, Rail on in utter ignorance Of what each other mean, And prate about an Elephant Not one of them has seen!}} [[Natalie Merchant]] sang this poem in full on her [[Leave Your Sleep]] album (Disc 1, track 13). == The meaning as proverb by country or domain == === Japan === In Japan, the proverb is used as a simile of circumstance that ordinary men often fail to understand a great man or his great work.{{Cite book|title=日本国語大辞典|last=|first=|work=小学館国語辞典編集部|publisher=小学館|year=2001-04-20|isbn=4-09-521004-4|edition=2|volume=4 きかく～けんう|location=Tokyo|pages=1188|language=ja|chapter=群盲象を評す}} ==Modern treatments== The story is seen as a [[metaphor]] in many disciplines, being pressed into service as an [[analogy]] in fields well beyond the traditional. In [[physics]], it has been seen as an analogy for the [[wave–particle duality]].For example, [https://books.google.com/books?id=9DWim3RhymsC&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=wave+particle+duality+elephant+blind+men&source=bl&ots=6G_1s_oA6v&sig=UaEauX5CaISP-azpgp0NXQCRwU0&hl=en&ei=YYaOS7WbOKf20gSH8-zmDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CA0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=wave%20particle%20duality%20elephant%20blind%20men&f=false ''Quantum theory''] by David Bohm, p. 26. Retrieved 2010-03-03. In [[biology]], the way the blind men hold onto different parts of the elephant has been seen as a good analogy for the [[Polyclonal B cell response]].See for instance ''The lymph node in HIV pathogenesis'' by Michael M. Lederman and Leonid Margolis, ''Seminars in Immunology'', Volume 20, Issue 3, June 2008, pp. 187–195.[[File:Blind men and elephant.png|thumb|"Blind men and elephant", from Martha Adelaide Holton & Charles Madison Curry, ''Holton-Curry readers'', 1914.]]The fable is one of a number of tales that cast light on the response of hearers or readers to the story itself. [[Idries Shah]] has commented on this element of [[self-reference]] in the many interpretations of the story, and its function as a [[teaching stories|teaching story]]:
...people address themselves to this story in one or more [...] interpretations. They then accept or reject them. Now they can feel happy; they have arrived at an opinion about the matter. According to their conditioning they produce the answer. Now look at their answers. Some will say that this is a fascinating and touching allegory of the presence of God. Others will say that it is showing people how stupid mankind can be. Some say it is anti-scholastic. Others that it is just a tale copied by Rumi from Sanai – and so on.{{cite web |url=http://www.idriesshah.info/Shah/ShahTeaStor.htm |title=The Teaching Story: Observations on the Folklore of Our "Modern" Thought |first=Idries |last=Shah |accessdate=2010-03-05}}
Shah adapted the tale in his book ''[[The Dermis Probe]]''. This version begins with a conference of scientists, from different fields of expertise, presenting their conflicting conclusions on the material upon which a camera is focused. As the camera slowly zooms out it gradually becomes clear that the material under examination is the hide of an African elephant. The words 'The Parts Are Greater Than The Whole' then appear on the screen. This retelling formed the script for a short four-minute film by the animator [[Richard Williams (animator)|Richard Williams]]. The film was chosen as an Outstanding Film of the Year and was exhibited at the London and New York film festivals.[http://www.octagonpress.com/titles/books/depr.htm Octagon Press page for The Dermis Probe] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726115510/http://www.octagonpress.com/titles/books/depr.htm |date=July 26, 2011 }}, with preview of story{{cite web|url=http://www.rockethouse.co.uk/Elephant/|title=touching the elephant|publisher=The Rockethouse|accessdate=21 August 2017}} The story enjoys a continuing appeal, as shown by the number of illustrated children's books of the fable; there is one for instance by [[Paul Galdone]] and another, ''Seven Blind Mice'', by [[Ed Young (illustrator)|Ed Young]] (1992). In the title cartoon of one of his books, cartoonist [[Sam Gross]] postulated that one of the blind men, encountering a pile of the elephant feces, concluded that "An elephant is soft and mushy." An [[elephant joke]] inverts the story in the following way:
Six blind elephants were discussing what men were like. After arguing they decided to find one and determine what it was like by direct experience. The first blind elephant felt the man and declared, 'Men are flat.' After the other blind elephants felt the man, they agreed.
Moral: {{quote|We have to remember that what we observe is not nature in itself, but nature exposed to our method of questioning.|[[Werner Heisenberg]]{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jz8LAQAAIAAJ&dq=editions:N9MRu2BM_V8C&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22We+have+to+remember+that+what+we+observe+is+not+nature+in+itself,+but+nature+exposed+to+our+method+of+questioning.%22|title=Physics and philosophy: the revolution in modern science|last=Heisenberg|first=Werner|date=1958|page=58|publisher=Harper|language=en}}}} [[Touching_the_Elephant_(radio_programme)|''Touching the Elephant'']] was a 1997 [[BBC Radio 4]] documentary in which four people of varying ages, all blind from birth, were brought to [[London Zoo]] to touch an elephant and describe their response.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p010x3qz|title=BBC Radio 4 Extra - 90 by 90 The Full Set, 1998: Touching The Elephant|work=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=21 August 2017}}{{cite book|last=Elmes|first=Simon|title=And Now on Radio 4: A Celebration of the World's Best Radio Station|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NlUP9X4wTMYC&pg=PA143|accessdate=21 August 2017|date=2009-11-10|publisher=Random House|isbn=9781407005287|page=143}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/radio-review-1136470.html|title=Radio Review|last=Hanks|first=Robert|date=3 January 1998|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=21 August 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/radio-tony-john-and-paddy-get-thee-to-a-nunnery-1268249.html|title=Radio: Tony, John and Paddy: get thee to a nunnery|last=Gaisford|first=Sue|date=19 April 1997|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=21 August 2017}} ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} * [[Anekantavada#Parable of the blind men and elephant|Anekantavada]] * [[Dispersed knowledge]] * ''[[Flatland|Flatland: A Romance of Many Dimensions]]'', an 1884 satirical novella * [[Hasty generalization]] * [[Rashomon effect]] * [[Syncretism]] * [[The blind leading the blind]] * [[Unreliable narrator]] * [[Wikipedia:Blind men and an elephant]], a Wikipedia essay ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Blind men and an elephant}} * {{cite wikisource|plaintitle=Masnavi I Ma'navi|chapter=Book III|anchor=STORY V. '''Blondell Wayne Tatum''', a.k.a. '''Chemo''', is a fictional character who has appeared in two novels by [[Carl Hiaasen]], ''[[Skin Tight (novel)|Skin Tight]]'' ([[1989 in literature|1989]]) and ''[[Star Island (novel)|Star Island]]'' ([[2010 in literature|2010]]).<ref>{{cite news|last=Wolff|first=Carlo|title=Celebrity culture gets skewered in ‘Star Island’|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2010/07/29/carl_hiaasen_skewers_celebrity_culture_in_star_island/|accessdate=11 August 2010|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=29 July 2010}}</ref>
==Personal history== Tatum was born in [[North Dakota]]. His parents belonged to a religious sect that believed in [[polygamy]], [[vegetarianism]], and [[Tax resistance|refusing to pay income taxes]]. Tatum was orphaned at age six when his parents were killed in a shootout with [[FBI]] agents in a post office outside [[Grand Forks, North Dakota|Grand Forks]]. He went to live with his aunt and uncle, who were fugitives from [[felony]] [[mail fraud]] charges in [[New Jersey]], masquerading as [[Amish]] wheat farmers in rural [[Pennsylvania]]. Blondell first turned to crime when he was sixteen ([[bank robbery|holding up a bank]] with a [[pitchfork]]), eventually becoming a corrupt, though popular, city official in a small Pennsylvania town.
His life took a drastic turn due to a freak accident during an [[electrology|electrolysis]] procedure to remove two ingrown hair follicles from the tip of his nose. While Tatum was unconscious, the doctor suffered a [[stroke]] and mistakenly applied the needle to his entire face. After Tatum woke up, he killed the doctor and fled the city, trying to find a cure for his facial condition. One wrongly-prescribed medication produced a lasting effect which "looked as if someone had glued [[Rice Krispies]] to every square centimeter of his face" and led to his nickname, "Chemo" (since many people wrongly assumed he was undergoing [[chemotherapy]]).
In [[Bal Harbour, Florida]], he approaches Dr. Rudy Graveline, a [[plastic surgeon]] who offers him a discount on [[dermabrasion]] treatments in exchange for Chemo killing Mick Stranahan, a former State Investigator who is causing Rudy worry.
During his first, failed attempt, Chemo drowns Stranahan's vengeful ex-wife, Chloe, with an anchor, after she points out the house she thinks is his. During his second, Chemo dives off the balcony of Stranahan's [[stilt house]] in [[Biscayne Bay]], and his hand is bitten off by a strike from Stranahan's pet [[Great Barracuda]].<ref name="wiemer">{{cite news|last=Wiemer|first=Robert|title=Mysteries: Why Are Those Guys Following Me?|newspaper=[[Newsday]]|date=5 November 1989}}</ref> Instead of a conventional prosthesis, he chooses to attach a portable [[String trimmer|weed whacker]].<ref name="justice">{{cite book|last=Van Dover|first=J. Kenneth|title=Isn't justice always unfair?: the detective in southern literature|year=1996|publisher=Popular Press|isbn=978-0-87972-723-9|pages=345|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4jrTkiGLmnsC&pg=PA345|author2=John F. Jebb|accessdate=12 August 2010|chapter=Miami Detectives}}</ref>
The whole affair spirals out of control, though Chemo is able to steal an amount of cash from Graveline that allows him to undergo a complete facial dermabrasion from a competent plastic surgeon. Although this treatment succeeds in removing the "Rice Krispies" effect, his surgeon advises him that he will still have to regrow the outer layer of his facial skin.
Eventually, Chemo is caught in a confrontation between Graveline and Stranahan out on the stilt house, where he kills Graveline out of fear (or mortification) that Graveline is about to confess the terms of the "deal" that he and Graveline had for killing Stranahan. Chemo is later arrested, and sentenced to four concurrent seventeen-year life sentences at [[Union Correctional Institution|Raiford]].
In 2010, he is back in Florida, having been paroled after 17 years, and enjoyed a lucrative spell of employment as a [[mortgage loan]] broker. After the [[subprime mortgage crisis|subprime mortgage bubble]] bursts, he is back to doing security, sometimes as a bodyguard for visiting celebrities. He carves out a small specialty for himself as a [[life coach]] for those with self-destructive addictions, since he has no awe whatsoever of fame, is immune to seduction, and not at all averse to beating his charges to pulp if they misbehave themselves. After pop star "Cherry Pye's" latest drug-and-alcohol escapade, her record promoter recruits Chemo to be her latest bodyguard, over the objections of her family.
==Appearance== Aside from his facial condition (which never completely recovers after the electrolysis mishap) and the weed trimmer attached to his arm, Chemo's appearance is also frightening because of his pallid, almost-reptilian complexion, the sparse hair on his scalp, and the fact that he stands 6'9" tall.<ref name="wiemer"/>
==Books with Chemo== * ''[[Skin Tight (novel)|Skin Tight]]'' * ''[[Star Island (novel)|Star Island]]''

{{DEFAULTSORT:Tatum, Blondell Wayne}} [[Category:Literary characters]] [[Category:Novels by Carl Hiaasen]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]]

{{unreliable sources|date=February 2018}} {{italic title}} [[Image:Brainwashing2.JPG|thumb|Cover of ''Brain-Washing'', as published by the [[Church of Scientology]] in 1955.]] '''''Brain-Washing: A Synthesis of the Russian Textbook on Psychopolitics''''', sometimes referred to as '''''The Brainwashing Manual''''', is a book published in 1955. It purports to be a condensation of the work of [[Lavrentiy Beria]], the [[NKVD|Soviet secret police]] chief. The book states [[Kenneth Goff]] as author. Its true authorship is not clear, the three common hypotheses being: Scientology's founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]], Kenneth Goff (alias Oliver Kenneth Goff), or both L. Ron Hubbard and Kenneth Goff based on an acquired US agency report.Introvigne 2005. The third hypothesis is questionable as there is not proof that the two men ever knew each other. Claims that L. Ron Hubbard was the author are also dubious as the only source of this claim is his estranged son, L Ron Hubbard Jr. It is also sometimes referred to as '''''The Communist Manual of Psycho-Political Warfare''''' or the '''''Communist Manual of Instructions of Psychopolitical Warfare'''''.[http://www.xenu-directory.net/practices/brainwashing2.html Brainwashing Manual - Timeline].. Specifically see [http://www.lermanet.com/exit/manney/1963_Ability_148_pg8-9.jpg Ability magazine 1963, volume 148, page 9], and a Letter to the Editor from a Van Nuys, CA newspaper, by Jackson Adams, entitled [http://www.xenu-directory.net/news/images/19580223-us-valleynews.pdf Psycho-Analysis and Mental Health Propaganda] Feb 23 1958 ==L. Ron Hubbard and Scientology== It says that it is a transcript of a speech on the use of [[psychiatry]] as a means of social control, given by [[Lavrenty Beria]] in the [[Soviet Union]] in 1950. However [[L. Ron Hubbard Jr.]], estranged son of Scientology founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]], stated:
"Dad wrote every word of it. Barbara Bryan and my wife typed the manuscript off his dictation."''[http://www.clambake.org/archive/books/mom/Messiah_or_Madman.txt L. Ron Hubbard: Messiah or Madman?]'' by Bent Corydon and L. Ron Hubbard, Jr.
Although Hubbard Jr.'s broad criticisms against his father were later discredited Hubbard's former editor, John Sanborn, confirmed Hubbard Jr.'s testimony. The Hubbard Association of Scientologists International published the booklet in an emergency basis in 1955. Hubbard tried to present the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] with a copy, but the Bureau expressed skepticism about the document's authenticity.''Bare-Faced Messiah'' by Russell Miller. CIA operative Edward Hunter called the book a hoax, while the evaluator at the Operations Coordinating Board of President Dwight D. Eisenhower’s National Security Council thought the writer of the booklet seemed to have a superior expertise on the subject.{{cite journal |title=Did L. Ron Hubbard Believe in Brainwashing? The Strange Story of the “Brain-Washing Manual” of 1955 |journal=Nova Religio: The Journal of Alternative and Emergent Religions, |year=2017 |last=Introvigne |first=Massimo |volume=20 |issue=4 |pages=62–79 |doi=10.1525/nr.2017.20.4.62 }} The book supposedly has Beria using obvious Hubbardisms such as "thinkingness" or "pain-drug-hypnosis", and making an unlikely mention of [[Dianetics]] side by side with [[Christian Science]] and [[Catholicism]] as major worldwide "healing groups". Modern versions of the book, make no mention of these so-called "Hubbardisms" thus refuting whether they in fact did appear in the original texts and thus the so-called authorship of Hubbard in the first place.http://www.pdf-archive.com/2014/06/02/the-soviet-art-of-brainwashing/http://www.everythingthatmattersradio.com/brainwashing2.html In 1963, the Australian Board of Inquiry regarded the book as written by Hubbard, something that neither Hubbard nor the Church of Scientology's HASI [[Hubbard Association of Scientologists International]] refuted at the time.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} According to [[Massimo Introvigne]], critics of Scientology attribute the Brainwashing manual to Hubbard because of the claim that it was later used to practice actual brainwashing in the church. However, “Hubbard’s works denounced brainwashing as something that should not be practiced, both on moral grounds and because brainwashing represented the triumph of everything Scientology found reprehensible and harmful in modern psychiatry.” Critics say that the proof is that Hubbard said in a 1956 Dianetics and Scientology bulletin: “We can brainwash faster than the Russians.” Introvigne purports that it was not an endorsement of brainwashing. The same bulletin also told Scientology auditors to “avoid these techniques typical of psychiatry.” There are two different meanings of brainwashing confused by critics of Scientology, says Introvigne. The first is drug-related, using psychotropic medication, violence and hypnosis, the second is “religious indoctrination,” which is generally used to attack not just the Church of Scientology but also other religions. The first is what Hubbard refers to as “pain-drug hypnosis,” which he declared ineffective and something to be “opposed and denounced” as a psychiatric practice. Hubbard expressed on December 1955 that there was no political significance attached to the booklet. “We couldn’t be less interested, but brainwashing happens to be a facet of the human mind and it has been necessary to make available to our own people any and all texts which exist on the subject.” He emphasized his interest was purely professional.{{cite journal |title=Did L. Ron Hubbard Believe in Brainwashing? The Strange Story of the “Brain-Washing Manual” of 1955 |journal=Nova Religio: The Journal of Alternative and Emergent Religions, |year=2017 |last=Introvigne |first=Massimo |volume=20 |issue=4 |pages=62–79 |doi=10.1525/nr.2017.20.4.62 }} ;The Anderson Report The final results of the [[Anderson Report]] in 1965 declared:
"The Board is not concerned to find that the scientology techniques are brainwashing techniques as practised, so it is understood, in some communist-controlled countries. Scientology techniques are, nevertheless, a kind of brainwashing... The astonishing feature of Scientology is that its techniques and propagation resemble very closely those set out in a book entitled ''Brain-washing'', advertised and sold by the HASI." ''[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dst/Cowen/audit/ar12.html Report of the Board of Enquiry into Scientology]'', by Kevin Victor Anderson, Q.C., Published 1965 by the State of Victoria, Australia.
==Kenneth Goff and the American far right== [[Morris Kominsky]] in his ''The Hoaxers: Plain Liars, Fancy Liars and Damned Liars'' (1970) attributes the authorship to a Rev. [[Kenneth Goff]] (alias Oliver Kenneth Goff) of [[Englewood, Colorado]], an assistant of [[Gerald L. K. Smith]]. The entirety of chapter twelve is devoted to analysis of the text and the author's correspondence with others to determine the authenticity of the text or points within it, and other publications which make reference to it. All current copies of the book including Kominsky's copy have a preface by Goff, but he does not give the publication date. The introduction begins:
"From May 2, 1936, to October 10, 1939, I was a dues-paying member of the Communist Party, operating under my own name, Kenneth Goff, and also the alias John Keats. In 1939, I voluntarily appeared before the Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C., which was chairmanned at that time by Martin Dies, and my testimony can be found in Volume 9 of that year's Congressional Report. During the period that I was a member of the Communist Party, I attended their school which was located at 113 E. Wells St., Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and operated under the name Eugene Debs Labor School. Here we were trained in all phases of warfare, both psychological and physical, for the destruction of the Capitalistic society and Christian civilization. In one portion of our studies we went thoroughly into the matter of psychopolitics. This was the art of capturing the minds of a nation through brainwashing and fake mental health -- the subjecting of whole nations of people to the rule of the Kremlin by capturing their minds. We were taught that the degradation of the populace is less inhuman than their destruction by bombs, for to an animal lives only once, any life is sweeter than death. The end of a war is the control of a conquered people. If a people can be conquered in the absence of war, the end of war will have been achieved without the destructions of war."
Kominsky owned another copy published by the "Ultra-Rightist women of the [[Burbank, California]] area who call themselves the [[American Public Relations Forum]], Inc." That copy included an introduction by [[Charles Stickley]] and with additional items by [[Usher L. Burdick]], claiming a publication date of 1955. Goff asserted Stickley plagiarized him, and that he had seen yet another publication which had done so. Nonetheless, the Goff version also makes no mention of so-called "Hubbardisms", which further disproves the alleged authorship by L. Ron Hubbard.http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/9319350-the-soviet-art-of-brainwashinghttps://www.fhu.com/articles/brainwashing1.html ==Notes== ==References== * [[Massimo Introvigne|Introvigne, Massimo]] (2005). [http://www.cesnur.org/2005/brainwash_13.htm "L. Ron Hubbard, Kenneth Goff, and the 'Brain-Washing Manual' of 1955"], [[CESNUR]] (Centro Studi sulle Nuove Religioni = Center for Studies on New Religions), www.cesnur.org *{{ cite web | url = http://www.xenu-directory.net/practices/brainwashing2.html | title = The Brainwashing manual: Timeline | accessdate = 2009-10-17 | publisher = xenu-directory.net }} (includes scanned images of many primary documents relating to the book, such as an FBI report on it, and some of Mr Hubbard's correspondence regarding it) ==External links== * [http://www.apfn.org/pdf/The_Brainwashing_Manual.pdf ''The Brainwashing Manual'' by L. Ron Hubbard] * [http://www.xenu-directory.net/critics/ambry1.html {{'}}''Brainwashing Manual'' Parallels in Scientology' by Brian Ambry] {{Scientology}} [[Category:1955 books]] [[Category:Books published by the Church of Scientology]] [[Category:Literary forgeries]] [[Category:Works of unknown authorship]]

{{Infobox television episode | title = Brian's a Bad Father | series = [[Family Guy]] | image = | caption = | season = 12 | episode = 11 | airdate = January 26, 2014 | production = BACX10 | writer = [[Chris Sheridan (writer)|Chris Sheridan]] | director = [[Jerry Langford]] | guests = * [[Ashley Benson]] as Dakota * [[Jim Breuer]] as [[Joe Pesci]] * [[Lucas Grabeel]] * [[Liam Neeson]] as himself * [[Emily Osment]] * [[Kevin Michael Richardson]] as [[Marvin Gaye]] | prev = [[Grimm Job]] | next = [[Mom's the Word]] | season_article = Family Guy (season 12) | episode_list = List of Family Guy episodes }} "'''Brian's a Bad Father'''" is the eleventh episode of the [[Family Guy (season 12)|twelfth season]] of the [[animated cartoon|animated]] [[television comedy|comedy series]] ''[[Family Guy]]'' and the 221st episode overall. It aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in the United States and Canada on January 26, 2014, and is directed by [[Jerry Langford]] and written by [[Chris Sheridan (writer)|Chris Sheridan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/family-guy-2014/episode-11-season-12/brians-a-bad-father/100148 |title=Family Guy Episode Guide 2014 Season 12 - Brian's a Bad Father, Episode 11 |publisher=TVGuide.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref>
In the episode, Brian's human son, Dylan, returns, now a teen TV star. Rather than being a good father to his estranged son, Brian uses his son's television connections to further his own writing career. Meanwhile, after Peter shoots Quagmire on a hunting trip, the two friends clash and Joe must choose a side.
==Plot== Brian's overlooked and neglected teenage son [[The Former Life of Brian|Dylan]] returns to Quahog. While Dylan tries to reconnect with his father, Brian tries to distance himself and ignore him. However, when he learns that Dylan is a now a cast member in a new [[Disney Channel]] television series, he — under the ruse of bonding — uses Dylan's connections to secure a job on the series' writing staff to further his career prospects. However, rather than work under age-appropriate guidelines, Brian tries to adapt the writing to include more mature content; because the material does not fit the network, Brian is fired by a producer. Furthermore, a disillusioned Dylan realizes that Brian is not interested in bonding but is merely using him for his own selfish ambitions, and tells him that he never wants to see him again. When Stewie sees Brian getting drunk out of depression, Brian realizes how selfish he has been and how he never realized that he had the chance to have Dylan back into his life again, but he pushed it aside. Stewie decides to help him apologize to Dylan. On the first try Brian gets beaten up after trying to sneak past security. However, right when they are about to leave, Stewie sees a casting line and successfully tries out for Dylan's show under one of his aliases. While recording, Stewie breaks character and explains to Dylan that Brian wants to apologize to him and become a true father to him. Dylan meets up at the local park with Brian and the two forgive each other.
Meanwhile, Peter, Quagmire and Joe go on a [[hunting]] trip. During a lunch break, Peter shoots Quagmire in his arm. When the three friends meet back at the bar, Quagmire tells Peter he is fed up with his shortsighted and reckless behavior, and ends their friendship. This causes a rift between the two and leads towards a contest for Joe's affection. In the end, Joe decides that Quagmire has helped him more through hard times and gets along better with the family and chooses Quagmire. Peter tries to bond with Kevin only to leave stating that Kevin is "masturbating with a knife". With no more friends and even his own shadow abandoning him for Quagmire, Peter decides to commit [[suicide]], which Lois talks him out of and persuades him to try and reconcile with Quagmire. Later on, Peter offers Quagmire the opportunity to shoot him to break even, thinking Quagmire would decline and consider the "thought" as being what counts. However, when Quagmire actually agrees, the two wrestle for the gun until Joe shoots Peter in an attempt to break even and stop the dispute. Peter (angry he was shot by Joe) and Quagmire (upset he was not the one who shot Peter) are dissatisfied. While Peter argues how everyone will settle their differences, Quagmire shoots Peter in the head making the score even. While Brian and Dylan are reconciling, Lois pushes a brain-damaged Peter in a wheelchair where Peter is explaining he is happy that he, Quagmire and Joe are friends again.
==Reception== Eric Thurm of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the episode a C–, saying "When so much of the episode is based on moving Brian from one end of the parenting spectrum to the other, that story has to be compelling, especially without that many jokes. But because it’s hard to buy Brian at the beginning, it’s difficult to watch this episode or take it that seriously (or as seriously as you’d ever take an episode of ''Family Guy'')."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/brians-a-bad-father-107283 |title=Family Guy: "Brian's A Bad Father"|publisher=Avclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref>
The episode received a 2.0 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic and was watched by a total of 4.11 million people. This made it the most watched show on [[Animation Domination]] that night, beating ''[[American Dad!]]'', ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'' and ''[[The Simpsons]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/01/28/sunday-final-ratings-60-minutes-the-bachelor-sean-and-catherines-wedding-adjusted-down-final-pro-bowl-grammy-awards-ratings/232506/ |title=Sunday Final Ratings: ’60 Minutes’ & ‘The Bachelor: Sean and Catherine’s Wedding’ Adjusted Down + Final Pro Bowl & Grammy Awards Ratings |publisher=Tvbythenumbers |date=2014-01-29 |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref> Including DVR viewing, the episode was watched by 5.83 million viewers, and received an 18-49 rating of 3.0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/02/10/live7-dvr-ratings-modern-family-has-biggest-18-49-ratings-gain-the-blacklist-tops-percentage-total-viewer-increase-in-week-18/235893/|title=Live+7 DVR Ratings: 'Modern Family' Has Biggest 18-49 Ratings Gain, 'The Blacklist' Tops Percentage & Total Viewer Increase in Week 18|work=TV by the Numbers|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|date=February 10, 2014|accessdate=February 10, 2014}}</ref>
