revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = I Saw the Devil | image = Isawthedevil.jpg | alt = | caption = Korean theatrical poster | film name = {{Film name | hangul = {{linktext|악|마|를}} {{linktext|보|았|다}} | hanja = {{linktext|惡|魔|}}를 보았다 | rr = Akmareul boatda | mr = Akmarŭl poatta}} | director = [[Kim Jee-woon]] | producer = Kim Hyung-woo
Jo Sung-won
Kim Jae-young
Kim Jung-hwa | writer = [[Park Hoon-jung]]
[[Kim Jee-woon]] | starring = [[Lee Byung-hun]]
[[Choi Min-sik]] | music = [[Mowg (composer)|Mowg]] | cinematography = [[Lee Mo-gae]] | editing = [[Nam Na-yeong]] | studio = | distributor = [[Showbox]]/Mediaplex | released = {{Film date|df=y|2010|8|12}} | runtime = 141 minutes | country = South Korea | language = Korean | budget = {{USD|6 million}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.screened.com/i-saw-the-devil/16-198531/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-09-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120626190233/http://www.screened.com/i-saw-the-devil/16-198531/# |archive-date=2012-06-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} | gross = {{USD|12.8 million}}[http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=isawthedevil.htm "''Boxofficemojo''"]. [[Boxofficemojo]]. Retrieved March 04, 2012. }} '''''I Saw the Devil''''' ({{ko-hhrm|악마를 보았다|惡魔를 보았다|Akmareul boatda}}) is a 2010 South Korean [[action film|action]][https://www.hancinema.net/korean_movie_I_Saw_the_Devil.php I Saw the Devil - HanCinema] [[horror film|horror]] [[thriller film]] directed by [[Kim Jee-woon]],{{cite news|last1=Kohn|first1=Eric|title=REVIEW: "I Saw the Devil" is Bloody Good Revenge|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2011/03/review-i-saw-the-devil-is-bloody-good-revenge-243458/|accessdate=11 January 2018|publisher=[[IndieWire]]|date=3 May 2011}} and written by Jee-woon and [[Park Hoon-jung]]. Starring [[Lee Byung-hun]] and [[Choi Min-sik]], the film follows NIS agent Kim Soo-hyun (Byung-hun), who embarks on a quest of revenge when his fiancée is brutally murdered by a psychopathic murderer, Jang Kyung-chul (Min-sik). ''I Saw the Devil'' made its [[premiere]] in the United States at the [[2011 Sundance Film Festival]] and had a [[Limited release|limited U.S theatrical release]].{{cite web |url=http://sundance.slated.com/2011/films/isawthedevil_sundance2011 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219162254/http://sundance.slated.com/2011/films/isawthedevil_sundance2011 |archivedate=2011-02-19 |df= }} ''I Saw the Devil'' was Choi Min-sik's first major role since the changes to the [[Screen quotas|Korean screen quota system]].{{Cite web|url=http://twitchfilm.com/news/2010/05/choi-min-sik-lee-byung-hyun-kim-ji-woon-i-saw-the-devil-teaser-arrives.php|title=''I Saw the Devil'' Teaser Arrives|first=Todd |last=Brown |date=28 May 2010|accessdate=2 April 2012}} ==Plot== Academy-bus driver Jang Kyung-chul runs into Jang Joo-yun one snowy night and offers to fix her flat tire. Kyung-chul kills her and scatters her body parts. When a boy discovers one of Joo-yun's ears, the police are called in under the command of Section Chief Oh and Squad Chief Jang (Joo-yun's father). Kim Soo-hyun, a secret service agent of the National Intelligence Service (NIS) and Joo-yun's fiancé, vows to track down and take vengeance on Joo-yun's murderer. Jang supplies Soo-hyun with a list of four suspects, including Kyung-chul. Searching Kyung-chul's home, Soo-hyun finds jewelry and underwear taken from numerous victims. The discovery of Joo-yun's engagement ring proves that Kyung-chul is the killer. Soo-hyun places a tracking device on the school bus, following and then attacking Kyung-chul while he is sexually assaulting his latest victim - one of the schoolgirls he was transporting home. Beating him unconscious, Soo-hyun places a NIS transmitter inside Kyung-chul, allowing him to track him on radar and listen to his conversations. Waking up, Kyung-chul flags down a taxi. During the ride, Kyung-chul realizes that the two men in the cab are thugs looking to rob and possibly kill him. He stabs both men to death. After finding the real taxi driver in the trunk, Kyung-chul disposes of all three bodies before going to a medical center, where he attempts to sexually assault a nurse Han Song-yi. Soo-hyun intervenes and slashes Kyung-chul's Achilles tendon before letting him go again. Kyung-chul goes to the home of his friend Tae-joo, a cannibalistic murderer. After explaining his situation, Tae-joo remarks that whoever is after him must have some relation to one of his victims. Soo-hyun arrives while Kyung-chul is having anal sex with Se-jung (Tae-joo's girlfriend), proceeding to incapacitate both murderers along with Se-jung after a fierce fight. The next day, both Tae-joo and Se-jung are found by the police and sent to a hospital. A trusted subordinate of Soo-hyun ensures he and Kyung-chul are sent to a private medical area away from the police. The barely conscious Kyung-chul hears them talk about the transmitter inside him. Soo-hyun dumps Kyung-chul, intending to continue stalking him. Kyung-chul taunts him over the transmitter, now knowing who he is. Kyung-chul brutally assaults a pharmacist while searching for laxatives, forcing Soo-hyun to rush to the aid of the victim. Kyung-chul uses this time to defecate out the transmitter and place it inside a taxi driver he viciously assaults in a public restroom. Soo-hyun interrogates Tae-joo and learns that Kyung-chul is going after Joo-yun's father Jang and sister Jang Se-yun. Soo-hyun is too late to stop Kyung-chul, who blinds Jang with a dumbbell and mutilates Se-yun. He narrowly abducts Kyung-chul before he can give up himself to the police. Soo-hyun tortures him before setting up a guillotine above Kyung-chul's head, which is triggered when his parents and son arrive to visit him and open the door to the room. Placing a transmitter nearby, Soo-hyun hears the death of Kyung-chul and his family's reaction to his decapitated corpse. Alternating between sobbing and fits of laughter, Soo-hyun suffers a mental breakdown while walking away from the house. ==Cast== * [[Lee Byung-hun]] as Kim Soo-hyun, an agent in the [[National Intelligence Service (South Korea)|National Intelligence Service]]{{cite web|last=Kang|first=Myoung-Seok|title=Lee Byung-hun says "'Devil' makes you think of what you get out of revenge"|url=http://10.asiae.co.kr/Articles/new_view.htm?sec=ent0&a_id=2010081917344982224|date=19 August 2010}} * [[Choi Min-sik]] as Jang Kyung-chul, an academy bus driver and serial killer * Oh San-ha as Jang Joo-yun, Soo-hyun's fiance * Jeon Gook-hwan as Squad Chief Jang, Joo-yun's father * [[Kim Yoon-seo]] as Jang Se-yun, Joo-yun's sister * [[Chun Ho-jin]] as Section Chief Oh, the leader of the police * [[Choi Moo-sung]] as Tae-joo, Kyung-chul's friend * [[Kim In-seo]] as Se-jung, Tae-joo's girlfriend * Yoon Chae-young as Han Song-yi, nurse * [[Nam Bo-ra]] as Section Chief Oh's daughter ==Alternate versions== The [[Korea Media Rating Board]] forced Kim to recut the film for its theatrical release, objecting to its violent content. The film received a "Restricted" rating twice, preventing any sort of release in theatres or on home video and promotions as well.{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118022720.html?categoryid=3768&cs|first=Han|last=Sunhee|title=Korea restricts 'Devil'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=9 August 2010}} Seven cuts were made with the total runtime of removed material between eighty and ninety seconds.{{cite web|url=http://twitchfilm.com/news/2010/08/i-saw-the-devil-trimmed-by-seven-cuts-not-by-seven-minutes.php|title=I SAW THE DEVIL Trimmed By Seven Cuts, Not By Seven Minutes|first=Todd|last=Brown|publisher=Twitch|date=13 August 2010|access-date=2011-03-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412123641/http://twitchfilm.com/news/2010/08/i-saw-the-devil-trimmed-by-seven-cuts-not-by-seven-minutes.php#|archive-date=2011-04-12|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Release== ''I Saw the Devil'' was released in South Korea on August 12, 2010. The film premiered at the [[2011 Sundance Film Festival]] on 21 January 2011. It also received screenings at several other international film festivals, including the [[Fantasporto]] Film Festival, [[Toronto International Film Festival]], [[Sitges Film Festival]], [[San Sebastian Film Festival]] and the London Korean Film Festival.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1588170/releaseinfo|title=I Saw the Devil (2010)|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}} American distribution rights were acquired by [[Magnet Releasing]] which released it in theatres on a limited basis on March 4, 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.beyondhollywood.com/red-band-trailer-and-new-u-s-poster-for-i-saw-the-devil|title=Red Band Trailer and New U.S. Poster for I Saw the Devil|publisher=Beyond Hollywood}} ===Critical reception=== Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave the film an 80% approval rating from critics based on 80 reviews and an [[Weighted arithmetic mean|average]] score of 7.1/10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/akmareul_boattda/|title=I Saw the Devil|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=2011-08-18}} [[Metacritic]] assigned the film a score of 67%, based on a weighted average of 19 reviews from mainstream critics.{{cite web | url= http://www.metacritic.com/movie/i-saw-the-devil | title=Metacritic: I Saw the Devil | publisher=[[CBS]] | work=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=2011-08-18}} Jeannette Catsoulis of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote, "From an unexpectedly moving first act to a hilariously disgusting sojourn with Kyung-chul’s cannibal pal, Mr. Kim and his cinematographer, Lee Mogae, retain complete control of the film’s fluctuating tones and impressive set pieces."{{cite news| url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2011/03/04/movies/04i-saw-the-devil.html | work=The New York Times | first=Jeannette | last=Catsoulis | title='I Saw the Devil' - Review | date=3 March 2011}} Mark Olson of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote, "There is all the violent mayhem, for certain, but the thing that sets ''I Saw the Devil'' apart is its undercurrent of real emotion and how unrelentingly sad it can be."{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/mar/04/entertainment/la-et-capsules-saw-devil-20110304 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Mark | last=Olsen | title=Movie review: 'I Saw the Devil' | date=4 March 2011}} Rob Nelson from ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine stated, "Repugnant content, grislier than the ugliest torture porn, ought to have made the film unwatchable, but it doesn't, simply because Kim's picture is so beautifully filmed, carefully structured and viscerally engaging."{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117943653?refcatid=31 | work=Variety | first=Rob | last=Nelson | title=I Saw the Devil | date=20 September 2010}} Horror website [[Bloody Disgusting]] gave it a 4.5/5 rating and stated, "I could talk for hours about I Saw the Devil, but nothing I can say will ever do it justice. The film is an experience; it’s something that will have you emotionally invested in the characters, while also covering your eyes at the extreme violence",{{cite news| url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/reviews/113902/i-saw-the-devil-limited-2/| work=Bloody Disgusting| title=I Saw the Devil | date=20 January 2011}} whereas ''[[Empire magazine|Empire]]'' awarded the film with a 4/5 score, stating, "This gleefully black horror-thriller is a very classy follow-up to ''The Good, the Bad, the Weird'' for Kim Jee-Woon".{{cite news| url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/review.asp?FID=137195| work=Empire| title=I Saw the Devil}} Phelim O'Neil from ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote, "There's no shortage of Korean revenge-thrillers, but this, along with the recent ''The Man from Nowhere'', proves there is plenty of life left in the genre" and gave it a four star rating out five.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/apr/28/i-saw-the-devil-review| work=The Guardian| title=I Saw the Devil}} Not all critics were favorable towards the film's brutality; Mark Jenkins of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote, "Director Kim Jee-woon is a born filmmaker, even if this script (written by Park Hoon Jung and adapted by Kim) is unworthy of his efforts" and rated it 2 out of 5 stars.{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/gog/movies/i-saw-the-devil-akmareul-boattda,1178295.html| work=Washington Post| title=I Saw the Devil}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' wrote, "On any number of levels, ''Devil'' is troublesome at best, offensive at worst".{{cite news | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/i-saw-devil-film-review-30159| work=The Hollywood Reporter| title=I Saw the Devil}} ''Rolling Stone'' magazine put ''I Saw the Devil'' in the top 20 of "the scariest movies you've never seen".{{cite news | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/lists/20-scariest-movies-you-need-to-see-20141029/i-saw-the-devil-2010-20141029 | title = I saw the devil}} ===Awards and nominations=== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" width="95%;" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! scope="col" | Award ! scope="col" | Category ! scope="col" | Nominee(s) ! scope="col" | Result |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | [[Asian Film Awards]] | Best Editor | [[Nam Na-yeong]] | {{won}} |- | Best Cinematographer | [[Lee Mo-gae]] | {{nom}} |- ! scope="row" rowspan="2" | [[Austin Film Critics Association]] | Best Foreign Language Film | rowspan="2"|''I Saw the Devil'' | {{won}} |- | Best Film | {{nom}} |- ! scope="row" rowspan="5" | [[31st Blue Dragon Film Awards|Blue Dragon Film Awards]] | Best Actor | [[Lee Byung-hun]] | {{nom}} |- | Best Cinematography | Lee Mo-gae | {{won}} |- | Best Art Direction | Cho Hwa-sung | {{nom}} |- | Best Music | [[Mowg (composer)|Mowg]] | {{won}} |- | Technical Award | Jeong Do-an, Lee Hee-kyung

{{Infobox film | name = Isn't It Romantic | image = Isn't It Romantic poster.jpg | border = no | caption = Teaser poster | director = [[Todd Strauss-Schulson]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Todd Garner]] * Grant Scharbo * [[Gina Matthews]] }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Erin Cardillo]] * [[Dana Fox]] * Katie Silberman }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Rebel Wilson]] * [[Liam Hemsworth]] * [[Adam DeVine]] * [[Priyanka Chopra]] }} | music = [[John Debney]] | cinematography = [[Simon Duggan]] | editing = Andrew Marcus | studio = [[New Line Cinema]]

[[Netflix]] (United Kingdom) | released = {{Film date|2019|2|14|United States}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Isn't It Romantic''''' is an upcoming 2019 American [[romantic film|romantic]] [[fantasy film|fantasy comedy]] film directed by [[Todd Strauss-Schulson]] and written by [[Erin Cardillo]], [[Dana Fox]], and Katie Silberman. The film stars [[Rebel Wilson]], [[Liam Hemsworth]], [[Adam DeVine]], and [[Priyanka Chopra]], and follows a woman who, after getting hit on the head, wakes up in a world where everything around her plays out like a rom-com film. The film is scheduled to be released in the United States on February 14, 2019, by [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] and in the United Kingdom on [[Netflix]]. ==Premise== For a long time, Natalie, an Australian architect living in New York City, had always believed that what she had seen in [[romantic comedies|rom-coms]] is all fantasy. But after thwarting a mugger at a subway station only to be knocked out while fleeing, Natalie wakes up and discovers that she is self-aware of her existence in a "[[PG-13]]" rom-com universe and must escape every cliché in order to finally fall in love and achieve the happily ever after that will bring her back to reality.{{cite web |url=https://ew.com/movies/2018/10/31/rebel-wilson-isnt-it-romantic-trailer/ |title=Watch a cynical Rebel Wilson navigate a cheesy rom-com in ''Isn't It Romantic?'' trailer |last=Sinha-Roy |first=Piya |date=October 31, 2018 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher= |access-date=November 1, 2018 |quote=}} ==Cast== * [[Rebel Wilson]] as Natalie, an architect from New York. * [[Liam Hemsworth]] as Blake, a client and one of two love interests in Natalie’s life. * [[Adam DeVine]] as Josh, Natalie’s best friend and one of two love interests in Natalie’s life. * [[Priyanka Chopra]] as Isabella, a yoga ambassador. * [[Betty Gilpin]] as Whitney, Natalie’s assistant and one of her best friends. * Brandon Scott Jones as Donny, Natalie's neighbor and gay sidekick. * [[Tom Ellis (actor)|Tom Ellis]] as a doctor. * [[Jennifer Saunders]] as Natalie’s mother. == Production == On May 23, 2016, it was reported that [[Rebel Wilson]] would be starring as Natalie in an untitled romantic comedy film by [[New Line Cinema]], from an original script by [[Erin Cardillo]] and rewrite by [[Dana Fox]] and Katie Silberman, while producers would be [[Todd Garner]], Grant Scharbo, and Gina Matthews.{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Rebel Wilson to Star in Romantic Comedy for New Line (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/rebel-wilson-romantic-comedy-new-line-1201781569/|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=Variety|date=May 23, 2016}} On March 22, 2017, [[Todd Strauss-Schulson]] was hired to direct the film, titled ''Isn't It Romantic'', while it was revealed that a latest draft of the script was done by [[Paula Pell]].{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Rebel Wilson’s Romantic Comedy Draws Director Todd Strauss-Schulson|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/rebel-wilson-isnt-it-romantic-director-todd-strauss-schulson-1202014395/|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=Variety|date=March 22, 2017}} On May 10, [[Adam DeVine]], who previously co-starred with Wilson in the first two [[Pitch Perfect]] movies, and [[Liam Hemsworth]] were cast in the film to play love interests in Natalie's life.{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Adam Devine, Liam Hemsworth Join Rebel Wilson in 'Isn't It Romantic' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/adam-devine-liam-hemsworth-join-rebel-wilson-isnt-romantic-1002480|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=May 10, 2017|language=en}} [[Priyanka Chopra]] was also cast in the film in May.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Priyanka Chopra Joins Rebel Wilson’s ‘Isn’t It Romantic,’ ‘A Kid Like Jake’ (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/priyanka-chopra-isnt-it-romantic-a-kid-like-jake-1202445935/|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=Variety|date=May 30, 2017}} On June 14, 2017, [[Betty Gilpin]] was cast in the film to play the Natalie's assistant Whitney, and one of her best friends.{{cite news|last1=Hipes|first1=Patrick|title=Betty Gilpin Joins Rebel Wilson In New Line’s ‘Isn’t It Romantic’|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/betty-gilpin-isnt-it-romantic-movie-casting-rebel-wilson-1202113390/|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=June 14, 2017}} [[Principal photography]] on the film began on July 10, 2017, in [[New York City]].{{cite news|last1=Perry|first1=Spencer|title=Production Begins on New Line's Isn’t It Romantic?|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/866875-production-begins-on-new-line-romantic-comedy-isnt-it-romantic|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=ComingSoon.net|date=July 10, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Rebel Wilson screams and waves her arms while filming her new movie|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-4683450/Rebel-Wilson-yells-filming-scene-new-movie.html|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=Mail Online|date=July 10, 2017}} == Release == ''Isn't It Romantic'' is scheduled to be released on February 14, 2019, by [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]].{{cite news|last1=D'Alessandro|first1=Anthony|title=‘Godzilla Vs. Kong’, ‘Game Night’ Among Many Warner Bros. Release Date Changes For 2018 & Beyond|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/godzilla-vs-kong-game-night-tag-scooby-warner-bros-release-date-changes-1202083542/|accessdate=July 11, 2017|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=May 3, 2017}} [[Netflix]] will handle international rights of the film.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|2452244}} * {{Twitter}} {{Todd Strauss-Schulson}} [[Category:Upcoming English-language films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American romantic fantasy films]] [[Category:Parallel universes in fiction]] [[Category:2010s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:2010s romantic fantasy films]] [[Category:Films shot in New York City]] [[Category:New Line Cinema films]] [[Category:2019 films]] [[Category:Upcoming films]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Netflix original films]]

{{Infobox Korean name | hangul = 금부 | hanja = {{linktext|金|鈇}} | mr = Kŭmbu | rr = Geumbu }}
'''''Keum-boo''''' (also '''''Kum-Boo''''' or '''''Kum-bu'''''—[[Korean language|Korean]] "attached gold") is an ancient [[Korea]]n [[gilding]] technique used to apply thin sheets of [[gold]] to [[silver]], to make [[silver-gilt]]. Traditionally, this technique is accomplished by first [[depletion gilding#Variations|depleting]] a surface of [[sterling silver]] to bring up a thin layer of [[Millesimal fineness#Silver|fine silver]]. Then [[Millesimal fineness#Gold|24 carat]] [[Metal leaf|gold foil]] is applied with heat and pressure—[[Gilding#Mechanical gilding|mechanical gilding]]—to produce a permanent [[diffusion]] bond.
Pure precious metals such as gold and silver have a very similar [[atomic structure]] and therefore have a good potential for bonding. Heating these metals to a temperature between 500–700°F increases the movement of the atoms. When pressure is added, this causes an electron exchange at the surface between the two metals, creating a permanent diffusion bond. This diffusion bond occurs far below the [[brazing|soldering]] temperature for either metal (Dhein, 2004).
Examples of this technique have probably been observed, but not positively identified on pieces from the second half of the first millennium B.C. and from the early first millennium A.D. (Oddy, 1981).
This technique is used in many cultures, including Chinese, Japanese and in the West to bond gold to other metals, including [[iron]], [[copper]], [[aluminum]], gold alloys, white gold, [[palladium]] and [[platinum]]. Foil made from gold alloys can be applied to silver and other metals by first [[depletion gilding]] the surface of the foil (Lewton-Brain, 1987–1993).
==References== *Dhein, Christine (2004). "[http://www.jewelryartistmagazine.com/stepbystep/aug04.cfm Keum-Boo Pillow Pendant]" *[[William Andrew Oddy|Oddy, Andrew]] (1981). "Gilding Through the Ages" *Lewton-Brain, Charles (1987–1993). "[http://www.ganoksin.com/borisat/nenam/keumboo.htm Keum-Boo]" *[http://www.calacademy.org/research/anthropology/tap/ARCHIVE/1998/1998-11--kumboo.html Korean Kum-Boo Metalwork], Traditional Arts Program Notes, 1998, Department of Anthropology, California Academy of Sciences.
[[Category:Artistic techniques]] [[Category:Gold]] [[Category:Metal plating]] [[Category:Korean art]]

page.title: Learned Society of the Czech Republic

revision.text:
The '''Learned Society of the Czech Republic''' ("Učená společnost České republiky") is an association of distinguished scholars of the [[Czech Republic]] from all scientific disciplines. Its goal is to support free conduct of research and furtherance of scientific knowledge. The Society was established in 1994 as a successor of The [[Royal Bohemian Society of Learning]] (founded in the end of the 18th century) and the [[Czech Academy of Sciences and Arts]] (founded in 1890).<ref>Hlavní aktivity Učené společnosti [online]. Učená společnost ČR, [cit. 2008-11-09]. {{cite web |url=http://www.learned.cz/main.php?id=01.01.04.00 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518095345/http://www.learned.cz/main.php?id=01.01.04.00 |archivedate=2009-05-18 |df= }}</ref>
Society membership is either as a Fellow (limited to 111 Fellows) or as an Honorary Fellow. The first elected president of the Learned Society of the Czech Republic was [[Rudolf Zahradník]] (1994–1997). Succeeding elected presidents were [[Josef Koutecký]] (1997–2002), [[František Šmahel]] (2002–2004), [[Jiří Grygar]] (2004–2008), [[Helena Illnerová]] (2008–2010), [[Václav Pačes]] (2010–2012), [[Petr Pokorný (intellectual)|Petr Pokorný]] (2012–2014), [[Jiří Bičák]] (2014–2016) and [[Zdeněk Havlas]] (2016–2018).
According to Act 83/1990, the Learned Society of the Czech Republic is a civic association. Its executive body is the Council of the Society.
The Czech Learned Society is a member of the Council of Scientific Societies of the Czech Republic.
The address of the Secretariat of the Learned Society of the Czech Republic is Národní 3, 110 00 Praha 1, Czech Republic,
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.learned.cz/en/ The Learned Society of the Czech Republic]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:National academies]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in the Czech Republic]]

page.title: List of fields of doctoral studies in the United States

revision.text:
This is the '''list of the fields of doctoral studies in the United States''' used for the annual Survey of Earned Doctorates, conducted by [[NORC at the University of Chicago]] for the [[National Science Foundation]] and other federal agencies, as used for the 2015 survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/statistics/srvydoctorates/surveys/srvydoctorates_2015.pdf|pages= 6 & 7 |title=Survey of Earned Documents questionnaire 2015 – Field of Study listing |publisher=NORC/NSF|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>
These are fields of [[Doctorate#Research-oriented doctorates|research-oriented doctoral studies]], leading mostly to [[PhD]]s – in the academic year 2014–15, 98% of the 55,006 research doctorates awarded in the U.S. were PhDs; 1.1% were [[EdD]]s; 0.9% were other research doctorates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/statistics/2017/nsf17306/data/taba2.pdf|title=Research degrees included in the Survey of Earned Doctorates: 2011–15|publisher=NSF|work=Doctorate Recipients from U.S. Universities: 2015|accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref> [[Professional degree]]s, though they are also considered doctorates (earned, not honorary), and do entitle the holder to call themselves "Doctor", such as [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]], [[Doctor of Dental Surgery|DDS]], [[Doctor of Veterinary Medicine|DVM]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]], [[Doctor of Pharmacy|DPharm]], [[Doctor of Ministry|DMin]] and [[Doctor of Psychology|PsyD]], are not included in the survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/statistics/2017/nsf17306/technotes.cfm#|title=Technical Notes|publisher=NSF|at=Survey Design|work=Doctorate Recipients from U.S. Universities: 2015|accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref>
==[[Life sciences]]== ===[[Agricultural sciences]]/[[natural resources]]===
*000 [[Agricultural Economics]] *003 Natural Resource/Environmental Economics (also in '''social sciences''') *010 [[Nutrition|Animal Nutrition]] *014 Animal Science, [[Poultry]] (or Avian) *019 [[Animal Science]], Other *020 [[Agronomy]] and [[Crop Science]] *025 Agricultural and Horticultural [[Plant breeding|Plant Breeding]] *030 [[Plant Pathology]]/[[Phytopathology]] (also in '''biological/biomedical sciences''') *039 [[Plant Sciences]], Other *043 [[Food science|Food Science]] *044 [[Food science|Food Science]] and [[Food technology|Technology]], Other *046 [[Soil chemistry|Soil Chemistry]]/[[Microbiology]] *049 [[Soil sciences|Soil Sciences]], Other *050 [[Horticulture|Horticulture Science]] *055 [[Fishing]] and [[Fisheries|Fisheries Sciences]]/[[Fisheries management|Management]] *066 [[Forestry|Forest Sciences and Biology]] *070 [[Forest management|Forest]]/[[Natural resource management|Resources Management]] *072 [[Wood|Wood Science]] and [[Paper|Pulp/Paper Technology]] *074 [[Natural resources|Natural Resources]]/[[Conservation (botany)|Conservation]] *079 [[Forestry]] and Related Science, Other *080 [[Wildlife management|Wildlife/Range Management]] *081 [[Environmental Science]] *098 [[Agricultural Science]]s/[[Natural Resources]], General *099 [[Agricultural Science]]s/[[Natural Resources]], Other
===[[Biological sciences|Biological]]/[[biomedical sciences]]===
