{{About|the company Synthetic Genomics|the field related to [[synthetic biology]]|Synthetic genomics}} {{Infobox organization | name = Synthetic Genomics | logo = [[File:Synthetic-genomics-logo.png|220px|Synthetic Genomics]] | type = [[Private company]] | key_people = {{ubl| Oliver Fetzer ([[CEO]])||[[J. Craig Venter]]|[[Hamilton O. Smith]]}} | board_of_directors = {{ubl|[[J. Craig Venter, Ph.D.]]|Oliver Fetzer, Ph.D, MBA|Reinhard J. Ambros, Ph.D||[[Juan Enriquez, MBA]]|David Kiernan, M.D., J.D|[[Kok-Thay Lim]]|William McKee|Tina Nova, Ph.D.|[[Alfonso Romo]]|[[Barry Schuler]]|Hamilton O. Smith. M.D.}} | services = {{ubl|[[Tissue engineering|Cell engineering]]|[[DNA sequencing]]|[[Plasmid preparation]]|[[Artificial gene synthesis|Custom Synthesis]]}} [[#Products|(Full list of services)]] | founder = [[J. Craig Venter Ph.D.]] | location_city = [[La Jolla|La Jolla, CA]] | area_served = Worldwide | products = [[Scientific instrument|Instruments]]
[[Reagents]]
[[Software as a service|Bioinformatics Tools]]
[[#Products|(Full list of products)]] | subsid = {{ubl|[http://www.sgidna.com SGI-DNA]|Synthetic Genomics Vaccines (SGVI)|Genovia Bio}} | homepage = {{URL|www.syntheticgenomics.com|SyntheticGenomics.com}} }} '''Synthetic Genomics Inc.''' ('''SGI'''), is a private company located in [[La Jolla]], California that is focused on the field of [[synthetic biology]]. SGI designs and builds [[systems biology|biological systems]] to address [[earth|global]] [[sustainability]] problems. [[Synthetic biology]] is an interdisciplinary branch of [[biology]] and engineering, combining fields such as [[biotechnology]], [[evolutionary biology]], [[molecular biology]], [[systems biology]], [[biophysics]], [[computer engineering]], and [[genetic engineering]]. Synthetic Genomics uses techniques such as [[software engineering]], [[Bioprocess engineering|bioprocessing]], [[bioinformatics]], biodiscovery, [[analytical chemistry]], [[fermentation]], cell [[optimization]], and [[Artificial gene synthesis|DNA synthesis]] to design and build biological systems. The company produces or performs research in the fields of sustainable [[bio-fuels]], insect resistant crops, [[Xenotransplantation|transplantable organs]], targeted medicines, DNA synthesis [[Scientific instrument|instruments]] as well as a number of biological [[reagents]]. ==Core markets== SGI mainly operates in three [[Strategic business unit|end markets]]: research, bioproduction and applied products. The [[research]] segment focuses on genomics solutions for academic and [[Contract research organization|commercial research organizations]]. The commercial products and services include [[Scientific insrument|instrumentation]], [[reagents]], [[artificial gene synthesis|DNA synthesis]] services, and [[bioinformatics]] services and [[Software as a service|software]]. In 2015, the company launched the BioXP 3200 system,{{cite web|title=SGI-DNA Launches the BioXp™ 3200 System Early Access Program|url=http://www.syntheticgenomics.com/040215.html|website=SGI-DNA}} a fully automated benchtop instrument that produces DNA fragments from many different sources for genomic data. The company's efforts in bio-based production are intended to improve both existing production [[Host (biology)|hosts]] and develop entirely new synthetic production hosts with the goal of more efficient routes to [[bioproducts]]. SGI has a number of commercial as well as research and development stage programs across a variety of industries. Some of these [[Strategic partnership|research partnerships]] include: {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |- ! scope="col" | Partner ! scope="col" | Focus ! scope="col" | Target |- ! scope="row" | [[United Therapeutics]] | [[Xenotransplantation|Organ Transplantation]] | To reduce the risk of rejection in organ transplantation{{cite web|title=Synthetic Genomics Inc. Expands Collaborative Research and Development Agreement with Lung Biotechnology PBC, a Subsidiary of United Therapeutics Corporation, to Develop Organs for Transplantation|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/synthetic-genomics-inc-expands-collaborative-research-and-development-agreement-with-lung-biotechnology-pbc-a-subsidiary-of-united-therapeutics-corporation-to-develop-organs-for-transplantation-300147402.html}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Novartis|Novartis Vaccines]] | [[Vaccines]] |To stockpile synthetic flu vaccines for rapid response to global flu outbreaks{{cite web|title=Novartis Teams with Synthetic Genomics Vaccines to Develop Flu Seed Virus Banks|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/novartis-teams-with-synthetic-genomics-vaccines-to-develop-flu-seed-virus-banks/81244037/}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Archer Daniels Midland|ADM]] | [[cooking oil|Food Oil]] | To provide nutritional oils that overcome cost barrier in multiple applications{{cite web|title=Synthetic Genomics and ADM partner for omega-3 DHA|url=http://www.algaeindustrymagazine.com/synthetic-genomics-adm-partner-omega-3-dha/}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Monsanto]] | [[Agriculture]] | To map microbiome metagenome related to plant health and crop yield{{cite web|title=Monsanto Acquires Parts of Agradis, Partners with Synthetic Genomics|url=http://www.xconomy.com/san-diego/2013/01/31/monsanto-acquires-parts-of-agradis-partners-with-synthetic-genomics/}} |- ! scope="row" | [[ExxonMobil]] | [[Biofuel|Biodiesel]] | To develop an algae platform that can produce economically viable biodiesel{{cite web|title=Exxon Sinks $600M Into Algae-Based Biofuels in Major Strategy Shift|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2009/07/14/14greenwire-exxon-sinks-600m-into-algae-based-biofuels-in-33562.html}} |} ==History== Synthetic Genomics was founded in the spring of 2005 by [[J. Craig Venter]], Nobel Laureate [[Hamilton O. Smith]], Juan Enriquez, and David Kiernan. J.Craig Venter (and Smith)'s previous company, [[Celera Genomics]], was a driving force in the race to sequence the [[Human Genome Project|human genome]].{{cite web |title=About Synthetic Genomics |work=Synthetic Genomics' corporate website |url=http://www.syntheticgenomics.com/about.htm |accessdate=November 26, 2005 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050924142325/http://syntheticgenomics.com/about.htm |archivedate = September 24, 2005}} The firm takes its name from the phrase [[synthetic genomics]] which is a scientific discipline of [[synthetic biology]] related to the generation of organisms artificially using genetic material.{{cite news |first=David |last=Whitehouse |title= Venter revives synthetic bug talk |date=July 4, 2005 |publisher=BBC |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4636121.stm}}{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1126/science.328.5981.958| pmid = 20488994| year = 2010| last1 = Pennisi | first1 = E.| title = Genomics. Synthetic genome brings new life to bacterium| volume = 328| issue = 5981| pages = 958–959| journal = Science}} Many of SGI's collaborations have been with energy companies. In 2007, SGI worked with BP to commercialize microbial-based processes for increasing the conversion and recovery of subsurface hydrocarbons.[http://www.syntheticgenomics.com/130607.html Press Release] In 2009, SGI received funding from [[ExxonMobil]] to produce [[biofuel]]s on an industrial-scale using recombinant [[algae]] and other microorganisms.[http://www.xconomy.com/san-diego/2009/06/04/craig-venter-has-algae-biofuel-in-synthetic-genomics-pipeline/ Juha-Pekka Tikka : ''Craig Venter Has Algae Biofuel in Synthetic Genomics’ Pipeline.'' Xconomy San Diego. 6/4/09.]{{cite news |title=Scientist on plan to turn algae to fuel |date=July 15, 2009 |publisher=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106658672}} The company purchased an 81 [[acre]] site in [[Southern California]]'s [[Imperial valley]] to produce [[algae fuel]] for their collaboration with Exxon Mobil.[http://www.algaeobserver.com/synthetic-genomics-inc-purchases-81-acre-site-in-south-california-desert#more-1033 Press Release] They also signed a collaborative agreement with [[New England Biolabs]] to Launch Gibson Assembly Master Mix Product for Synthetic and Molecular Biology Applications in 2012.[https://www.genomeweb.com/pcrsample-prep/synthetic-genomics-new-england-biolabs-partner-commercialize-dna-assembly-produc Article] In 2010, Synthetic Genomics spun off a new subsidiary, Synthetic Genomics Vaccines Inc., to develop next generation [[vaccines]][http://www.xconomy.com/san-diego/2010/10/07/venter-institute-synthetic-genomics-form-vaccine-company-partner-with-novartis/ Press Release] In 2014 SGI expanded into the field of [[organ transplantation]] with a collaborative agreement with [[United Therapeutics]] valued at $50M[http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2014/may/06/synthetic-genomics-pigs-lung-therapeutics/ Article] and brought in Oliver Fetzer as [[CEO]].[http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2014/oct/27/synthetic-genomics-ceo-fetzer-venter/ Union Tribune Article] ==Products== Commercialized products sold by Synthetic Genomics are sold through its subsidiary company [http://www.sgidna.com SGI-DNA]. Many of these products utilize the [[Gibson assembly|Gibson assembly method]] which was created by Dan Gibson (currently the Vice President of DNA Technology at SGI) in collaboration with the [[J. Craig Venter Institute]] in 2009. ===Reagents=== *[https://www.sgidna.com/hifi_kit.html Gibson Assembly HiFi 1-Step Kit] *[https://www.sgidna.com/ultra_kit.html Gibson Assembly Ultra Kit] *[https://www.sgidna.com/sdm-kit.html Gibson Assembly Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit] *[https://www.sgidna.com/ga-vectors.html Gibson Assembly Vectors] ===Instruments=== *[https://www.sgidna.com/bxp3200.html BioXp 3200 System] === '''Cells''' === * [https://www.sgidna.com/vmax-express.html Vmax Express Chemically Competent & Electrocompetent Cells] ===Software=== *[https://www.sgidna.com/archetype.html Archetype software] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.syntheticgenomics.com/}} [[Category:Biotechnology companies]] [[Category:Genetic engineering]] [[Category:Synthetic biology]] [[Category:Algae biomass producers]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox company | slogan = | name = The Chelsea Cobbler | logo = | foundation = 1967 | founder = Richard Smith, Amanda Wilkins, George Macfarlane | location_city = London | location_country = England | key_people = | industry = Shoe manufacturer and retailer | products = | revenue = | operating_income= | net_income = | num_employees= | parent = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes =}} '''The Chelsea Cobbler''' (also sometimes '''Chelsea Cobbler''') is a British shoe brand that was established in the 1960s in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]].
Originally a high-fashion brand creating bespoke (made-to-measure) shoes, it was regularly featured in catwalk shows and the fashion press throughout the 1970s, when it also had a retail presence in New York City. It was twice chosen as part of the [[Dress of the Year]] ensemble displayed at the [[Fashion Museum, Bath]].
Later the brand was absorbed into larger fashion companies. It was relaunched in 2009.
==Brand establishment== The Chelsea Cobbler's first store opened in April 1967 in Draycott Avenue, Chelsea. The founders were Richard Smith (also the shoe designer), Amanda Wilkins and George Macfarlane.<ref name="The Times 57236">{{cite news|last1=King-Deacon|first1=Antony|title=Men's fashion by Antony King-Deacon|issue=57236|work=The Times|date=26 April 1968|ref=pg.3}}</ref> Writing in ''[[The Times]]'' in 1968, Antony King-Deacon said the brand's shoes cost from 9 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]] and the founders were: "trying to get the public to accept well-made, rather expensive shoes". King-Deacon's comments were within an article bemoaning the poor quality of mass shoe production and describing the re-emergence of small and bespoke designers.<ref name="The Times 57236"/> This was in an era when the UK shoe market was dominated by lower-priced brands within the [[Sears|British Shoe Corporation]]; its stores accounted for an estimated 25 to 30 per cent of retail shoe sales in the UK at the end of the 1960s.<ref name="The Times 57715">{{cite news|last1=Lumsden|first1=Andrew|title=Which path for shoemakers?|issue=57715|work=The Times|date=12 November 1969|ref=pg.27}}</ref> The factory which was in Mornington Crescent was run by Spiros Mina and Antony Achilleos. Arty Achilleos was an apprentice here.He later started his own business Baboucha.
A year later, [[Prudence Glynn]] featured The Chelsea Cobbler, alongside [[Rayne (shoe company)|Rayne]], [[Moya Bowler]], [[Ravel (shoe company)|Ravel]] and [[Bruno Magli|Magli]] in an article about London's best specialist shoe shops. By this stage, the brand also had a shoe shop in [[Sackville Street, London|Sackville Street]] in the [[West End of London|West End]].<ref name="The Times 57636">{{cite news|last1=Glynn|first1=Prudence|title=That's shoe business|issue=57636|work=The Times|date=12 August 1969|ref=pg.11}}</ref> Also in 1969, Richard Smith of Chelsea Cobbler and Glen Carr of Norvic were chosen to show off the versatility of a new leather substitute created by British company [[Chloride Electrical Storage Company]] and known as Porvair. Smith's shoes were worn with men's clothing created by hip womenswear designer [[Clive Evans (fashion designer)|Clive Evans]] at the launch event.<ref name="The Times 57699">{{cite news|last1=Deacon-Smith|first1=Antony|title=Men's Fashion|issue=57699|work=The Times|date=24 October 1969|ref=pg.15}}</ref>
In 1969, Mirabel Walker described it as among a crop of new shoe design companies that had caught up with continental Europe's design approach, saying: "The Chelsea Cobbler...make shoes in any colour, any style, to suit any foot".<ref name="The Guardian Walker">{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Mirabel|title=Glorious Jumble|work=The Guardian|date=17 July 1969|ref=pg.7}}</ref>
==1970s expansion== In 1970, The Chelsea Cobbler was chosen as part of the Dress of the Year ensemble. Its blue suede boots were worn in combination with a [[Bill Gibb]] plaid maxi skirt and a waistcoat by [[Kaffe Fassett]]. The outfit's selector was ''[[Vogue (British magazine)|Vogue]]'' editor [[Beatrix Miller]].<ref name="FMB, DotY">{{cite web|title=Dress of the Year|url=http://www.fashionmuseum.co.uk/galleries/dress-year|website=fashionmuseum.co.uk|accessdate=3 June 2015|publisher=Fashion Museum, Bath}}</ref> Also in 1970, ''The Times'' featured its novelty canvas boots supplied with [[Iron-on|iron-on transfers]], enabling people to customise their footwear by decorating the canvas in acrylic paints. The boots were priced at 12 guineas a pair.<ref name="The Times 57840">{{cite news|title=Paint your own boots|issue=57840|work=The Times|date=10 April 1970|ref=pg.14}}</ref> By this stage, as Prudence Glynn reported, fashionable shoppers were in the grip of boot "fever": "The British, of course, love queueing and the new generation of standers in line can be seen any day in The Chelsea Cobbler or Annello and Davide preparing to wait eight to 12 weeks for a pair of boots to be made. The boot fever is such that even the Parisiennes must wait because stocks sell as fast as they are delivered".<ref name="The Times 58001">{{cite news|last1=Glynn|first1=Prudence|title=Fashion by Prudence Glynn|issue=58001|work=The Times|date=20 October 1970|ref=pg.12}}</ref>
In 1971, the company was among the accessories designers featured in an exhibition showcasing British talent at [[The Louvre]] – at the invitation of the director of [[Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris|Musée des Arts Décoratifs]] – entitled ''L'Idee de la Forme''. Fashion designers in the mix included [[Christopher McDonnell]], [[Barbara Hulanicki]], [[Mary Quant]], [[Jean Muir]], Bill Gibb and [[Women's Home Industries|Beatrice Bellini]].<ref name="The Times Glynn 58134">{{cite news|last1=Glynn|first1=Prudence|title=Brittania Crosses the Waves|issue=58134|work=The Times|date=30 March 1971}}</ref> That year, the company was also producing boots – wide-legged and in quilted suede with wooden heel and platform – for main branches of [[Russell & Bromley]].<ref name="The Times 58258">{{cite news|last1=Glynn|first1=Prudence|title=Coming Attractions|issue=58258|work=The Times|date=24 August 1971|ref=pg.12}}</ref> In 1972, a branch opened in New York City.<ref name=schiro>{{cite news|last=Schiro|first=Anne-Marie|title=Fit. Comfort Most Important .These Shoe Designers Sell, And Wear Their Shoes|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1870&dat=19800316&id=_4sfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NtMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1206,806196 |accessdate=19 February 2014 |newspaper=Daytona Beach Sunday News-Journal |date=16 March 1980}}</ref>
By 1973, The Chelsea Cobbler had its own department within [[Harrods]]' 'Way In' fashion department.<ref name="The Times 58914">{{cite news|title=Picture Page|issue=58914|work=The Times|date=16 October 1973|ref=pg.12}}</ref> Prudence Glynn reported that the leather company [[Barrow Hepburn]] had taken a controlling interest, saying: "I approve of Barrow Hepburn's controlling interest in Chelsea Cobbler. Richard Smith, who heads the latter, has very sensitive antennae and a very sure style. With Manolo Blahnik of Zapata, he shares the favours to top fashion designers in this country who use his shoes to complement their clothes".<ref name="The Times 58914"/> Two years later, The Chelsea Cobbler was once again chosen as part of the Dress of the Year ensemble, this time for a pair of men's shoes worn with a [[Tommy Nutter]] suit and chosen by the editor of the UK edition of ''[[Brides (magazine)|Brides]]''.<ref name="FMB, DotY"/>
In 1976, it was reported that Richard Smith would be creating a shoe design for Rayne.<ref name="The Times 59666.">{{cite news|last1=Glynn|first1=Prudence|title=Shopping|issue=59666.|work=The Times|date=30 March 1976|ref=pg.10}}</ref> By 1978, The Chelsea Cobbler had branches in [[Bond Street|New Bond Street]], [[Fulham Road]] and [[King's Road]], as well as concessions in Harrods and [[Bentalls]] in [[Kingston upon Thames|Kingston]].<ref name="The Guardian 23061978">{{cite news|title=Hot on the Heel of Fashion (advert)|work=The Guardian|date=23 June 1978|ref=pg.25}}</ref>
In 1979, Rayne acquired The Chelsea Cobbler business from Barrow Hepburn for £150,000.<ref name="The Guardian 030179">{{cite news|title=Bids & Deals|work=The Guardian|date=3 January 1979|ref=p.14}}</ref>
==Later history== In 1993, both The Chelsea Cobbler brand and Rayne were absorbed into [[Nine West]], an American shoe company that would later buy [[Pied a Terre (shoe company)|Pied a Terre]].<ref name="The Times 65925">{{cite news|last1=Cunningham|first1=Sarah|title=Americans step into UK shoes|issue=65925|work=The Times|date=25 June 1997|ref=pg.31}}</ref> By 2004, the brand was part of [[Mosaic Fashions|Shoe Studio Group]].<ref name="FT Buckley">{{cite news|last1=Buckley|first1=Sophy|title=Baugur set to increase footprint on high street|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/0a7b8fc4-32be-11d9-8498-00000e2511c8.html|accessdate=4 July 2015|work=Financial Times|date=10 November 2004}}</ref> By 2008, it was under the ownership of [[Baugur Group]].<ref name="The Times 69293.">{{cite news|title=Shopping Basket: What Baugur Owns in the UK|issue=69293|work=The Times|date=9 April 2008|ref=pg.50}}</ref> In 2009, Shoe Studio Group assets were sold to the footwear brand [[Dune Group (footwear brand)|Dune Group]].<ref name="Drapers Brown">{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Jessica|title=Shoe Studio Group sold to Dune|url=http://www.drapersonline.com/news/footwear/shoe-studio-group-sold-to-dune/5001056.article|accessdate=4 July 2015|publisher=Drapers|date=3 March 2009}}</ref>
Chelsea Cobbler was relaunched as a menswear brand by Dune in 2009. Standalone stores were opened in [[South Molton Street]] and [[Fenwick (department store)|Fenwick]] in [[Brent Cross|Brent Cross Shopping Centre]]. In 2012, a Chelsea Cobbler men's shoes concession opened within [[TopShop|Topman]] Oxford Circus.<ref name="Drapers Ryan">{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=John|title=Chelsea Cobbler, Mayfair, London|url=http://www.drapersonline.com/news/footwear/shopwatch/chelsea-cobbler-mayfair-london/5008640.article|accessdate=3 July 2015|publisher=Drapers|date=5 December 2009}}</ref><ref name="WJ Chelsea Cobbler">{{cite news|title=Dune opens Chelsea Cobbler|url=http://wjlondon.com/dune-opens-chelsea-cobbler/|accessdate=3 July 2015|publisher=WJ London|date=8 March 2012}}</ref> These stores however were closed by Dune.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://collections.vam.ac.uk/search/?listing_type=&offset=0&limit=15&narrow=&extrasearch=&q=Chelsea+Cobbler&commit=Search&quality=0&objectnamesearch=&placesearch=&after=&after-adbc=AD&before=&before-adbc=AD&namesearch=&materialsearch=&mnsearch=&locationsearch= Chelsea Cobbler shoes at the Victoria & Albert Museum]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chelsea Cobbler}} [[Category:Shoe companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Shoe designers]] [[Category:High fashion brands]] [[Category:British companies established in 1967]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1967]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in England]] [[Category:1960s fashion]] [[Category:1970s fashion]] [[Category:1980s fashion]] [[Category:2000s fashion]] [[Category:2010s fashion]] [[Category:British brands]] [[Category:Luxury brands]]

{{Infobox book | | name = The Golden Calf | title_orig = Золотой телёнок | translator = | image = Zolotoy telenok.jpg | caption = | author = [[Ilf and Petrov]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Soviet Union | language = [[Russian language|Russian]] | series = | genre = [[Satire|Satirical novel]] | publisher = | release_date = 1931 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = | isbn = 1-934824-07-0 | preceded_by = [[The Twelve Chairs]] | followed_by = }} '''''The Little Golden Calf''''' ({{lang-ru|Золотой телёнок}}, ''Zolotoy telyonok'') is a satirical novel by Soviet authors [[Ilf and Petrov]], released in 1931. Its main character, [[Ostap Bender]], also appeared in a previous novel by the authors called ''[[The Twelve Chairs]]''. The title alludes to the "[[golden calf]]" of the [[Bible]]; another possible rendering of it in English, less literal but better tuned to the air of the novel, would be "The Gilded Calf". ==Plot summary== [[Ostap Bender]] is still alive (but sports a scar across his neck), after barely surviving the assassination attempt in the previous book, which he once briefly mentions as "stupid business". This time he hears a story about a "clandestine [[millionaire]]" named Alexandr Koreiko. Koreiko has made millions through various illegal enterprises by taking advantage of the widespread corruption in the [[New Economic Policy]] (NEP) period while pretending to live on an office clerk's salary of 46 rubles a month. Koreiko lives in ''Chernomorsk'' (literally: [[Black Sea]] city, referring to the city of [[Odessa]]) and keeps his large stash of ill-gotten money in a suitcase, waiting for the fall of the Soviet government, so that he can make use of it. Together with two petty criminals Balaganov and Panikovsky, and an extremely naive and innocent car driver Kozlevich, Bender finds out about Koreiko and starts to collect all the information he can get on his business activities. Koreiko tries to flee, but Bender eventually tracks him down in [[Turkestan]], on the newly built [[Turkestan–Siberia Railway]]. He then blackmails him into giving him a million rubles. Suddenly rich, Bender faces the problem of how to spend his money in a [[Communist]] country where there are no legal millionaires. Nothing of the life of the rich that Bender dreamt of seems possible in the Soviet Union. Frustrated, Bender even decides to anonymously donate the money to the [[Ministry of Finance (Soviet Union)|Ministry of Finance]], but changes his mind. He turns the money into [[jewelry|jewels]] and [[gold]], and tries to cross the [[Romania]]n border, only to be robbed by the Romanian border guards, leaving him only with a medal, the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]]. == Main characters == *[[Ostap Bender|Ostap Ibragimovich Bender]], the main character and protagonist *Shura Balaganov, the second "Son of Lieutenant Schmidt" *Mikhail Samuelevich Panikovsky, the third "Son of Lieutenant Schmidt" *Adam Kazimirovich Kozlevich, a taxi "Wildebeest" ({{lang-ru|"Антилопа Гну"}}) driver *Alexander Ivanovich Koreiko, a millionaire == Two endings == There are two alternative endings to ''The Golden Calf''. One was written at the time the novel was originally submitted for publication to the magazine ''Thirty Days''. The other appeared later, probably due to the objections to the writers for lionizing their main character. According to the first, Ostap Bender, after obtaining his "million", gets to know the sorrow of a lonely man who has fulfilled his purpose, renounces the fortune, and marries his beloved, Zoya Sinitskaya. In the second, he is torn. At first, he returns his "million" to the Commissariat of Finance, but then changes his mind. Determined to travel to [[Rio de Janeiro]], he is caught crossing the Romanian border and sent back home, after being deprived of his fortune by Romanian border guards.
“No ovations! I failed to become [[the Count of Monte Christo]]. I’ll have to retrain as an apartment manager”.Не надо оваций! Графа Монте-Кристо из меня не вышло. Придется переквалифицироваться в управдомы. (the 1932 English translation reads: "I shall have to qualify as a janitor")
==Cultural influence== The book contributed a number of [[catchphrase]]s and colorful terms into the [[Russian language]], such as "''Horns and Hoofs'' company ("Рога и копыта")" and "[[Children of Lieutenant Schmidt]]", see the [[q:The Little Golden Calf|Wikiquote]] page for the book for more. ===Adaptations=== [[Mikhail Shveytser]] made a black-and-white film ''[[The Golden Calf (1968 film)|The Golden Calf]]''{{IMDb title|0063845|Zolotoy Telyonok}} in 1968, with [[Sergey Yursky]] as Bender. In [[1993 in film|1993]], it was adapted as ''Mechty Idiota'' (Idiot's Dreams) by director [[Vasili Pichul]], starring pop singer [[Sergei Krylov (singer)|Sergei Krylov]] as Bender. In 2006, the Russian [[Channel One (Russia)|Channel One]] aired the eight-part TV series ''{{Interlanguage link|The Golden Calf (TV series)|lt=The Golden Calf|ru|Золотой телёнок (телесериал)}}'' starring [[Oleg Menshikov]] as Bender. The 2009 translation into English, ''The Little Golden Calf'' by Annie O. Fisher (published by Russian Life Books) was the first unabridged, uncensored translation into English of the novel.[http://www.russianlife.com/books/fiction/the-little-golden-calf/ The Little Golden Calf] ''[[Russian Life]]'', retrieved 9/6/2015. The translation won the 2010 AATSEEL Award for Best Translation into English from any Slavic Language. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|The Little Golden Calf|The Little Golden Calf}} {{wikiquote2|ru:Золотой телёнок|The Golden Calf (Russian Wikiquote)}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051218000444/http://lib.ru/ILFPETROV/telenok.txt Full Russian text at lib.ru] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060316171524/http://www.idlewords.com/telenok/ Free online English translation (in progress)] {{The Twelve Chairs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Golden Calf, The Little}} [[Category:Soviet novels]] [[Category:1931 novels]] [[Category:Literary collaborations]] [[Category:Russian comedy novels]] [[Category:Russian novels adapted into films]] [[Category:Novels set in Odessa]] [[Category:Ilf and Petrov]] [[Category:Picaresque novels]] [[Category:Satirical novels]]

page.title: The Other Log of Phileas Fogg

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Other Log of Phileas Fogg | title_orig = | translator = | image = Image:Other Log of Phileas Fogg.jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[Philip José Farmer]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = [[Jack Gaughan]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Science Fiction]], [[Steampunk]] | publisher = [[Daw Books]] | release_date = [[1973 in literature|1973]] | media_type = Print (paperback) | pages = 304 | isbn = 0-8125-2468-3 | oclc = 221324590 | preceded_by = [[Time's Last Gift]] | followed_by = [[Traitor to the Living]] }}
'''''The Other Log of Phileas Fogg''''' is a science fiction/[[steampunk]] [[parallel history]] novel written by American author [[Philip José Farmer]] in 1973. It was originally published by [[DAW Books]] and later reprinted in 1979 by Hamlyn and again in 1982 by [[Tor Books]]. Tor has subsequently reissued the novel in 1988 and 1993.
==Plot introduction==
The story takes place within the internal reality first imagined in the 1872 [[Jules Verne]] novel, ''[[Around the World in Eighty Days (novel)|Around the World in Eighty Days]]''. Farmer includes many of the story's original characters, including [[Phileas Fogg]] and his French valet, [[Jean Passepartout|Passepartout]]. He establishes that all of Verne's published works take place within the same shared continuity. He includes elements of [[crossover fiction]], incorporating the [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] characters of [[Sherlock Holmes]] and [[Professor Moriarty|James Moriarty]] into his setting. These elements place Phileas Fogg and his entire supporting cast into the [[Wold Newton family]] of literary characters.
In an introduction, Farmer posits that Verne's story was not simply an article of fiction, but the chronology of actual events, which Verne later decided to adapt into a fictional setting. In the book's epilogue, Farmer playfully alludes to the notion that Phileas Fogg is still alive, and may in fact be the actual author of the story (Farmer notes that they both share the same initials, suggesting that Philip Farmer is actually an alias for Phileas Fogg).
From Farmer's perspective, Jules Verne revealed only a small and significantly subdued portion of the actual background and exploits of Phileas Fogg. He establishes that the events surrounding ''Around the World in Eighty Days'' is actually a singular aspect of a greater conflict taking place between two immortal alien races, the Eridani and the Capellas. Farmer's story does not challenge any of the elements of the original text, but rather it adds an ambitious secondary tale taking place behind (and often in between) the scenes of Verne's material.
==Plot summary==
Phileas Fogg is a mysterious British gentleman who lives with his valet Passepartout at No. 7 Saville-Row in [[Burlington Gardens]] during the latter half of the 19th century. Unbeknownst to his peers, he is also the immortal foster child of a race of humanoid aliens known as the Eridani. A man of great intellect and affluence, Fogg enters into a wager with a fellow Eridanian citing that he can circumnavigate the globe in exactly eighty days. Although witnesses feel that his claim is little more than the boasting of a rich eccentric, Fogg is in fact undertaking a secret mission on behalf of his Eridanian colleagues.
Along with Passepartout, Fogg begins a quest to find a piece of stolen alien technology – a teleportation device that had recently fallen into the hands of the Eridani's rivals, an alien race known as the Capellas. His journey brings him face to face with the infamous sea scourge [[Captain Nemo]], a Capellan agent who is also known in British circles by his [[nom de guerre]] – [[Professor Moriarty|James Moriarty]]. The two combatants match wits with one another at several key locations, including the mysterious ghost ship known as the ''[[Mary Celeste]]''.
The journey climaxes with a final battle at Fogg's home in London, mere moments before meeting the deadline required to win his world-spanning wager.
==See also== {{portal|Novels}} * [[Doc Savage: His Apocalyptic Life]] * [[Wold Newton family]]
==Notes== The novel concludes with a twenty-one page addendum written by H.W. Starr entitled "A Submersible Subterfuge or Proof Impositive". It originally appeared in ''Leaves from the Copper Beeches'' and published for the Sons of the Copper Beeches Scion Society of the [[Baker Street Irregulars]]; Livingston Publishing Company, [[Narberth, Pennsylvania|Narberth]], 1959.
Starr exhaustively details the irreconcilable inconsistencies that take place within Verne's ''Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea'', and its companion novel, ''[[The Mysterious Island]]'' (which likewise features the character of Captain Nemo). He further contrasts the life and personality of Nemo, as originally presented by Verne, with that of James Moriarty – nemesis of [[Sherlock Holmes]]. Information contained within the addendum actually challenges Farmer's merging of both characters, citing specific comparisons of age, personality and lineage.
